entrydata.text: 50 Park Road, du Toit Allsopp Hillier/ du Toit Architects Limited

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: Completed in 1954, the building was designed as the first permanent headquarters for the O.A.A. The new headquarters was critically acclaimed in press reports and architectural publications of the period as a landmark modern building in Toronto. It was also a success as a unifying focal point for Toronto's architects, its high profile injecting renewed pride and energy into the profession at a critical time in the city's development. In the early 1990s, the building was modified for du Toit Allsopp Hillier | du Toit Architects Limited to suit the needs of a contemporary architectural office while at the same time attempting to give back to the interior a sense of the openness, simplicity and spatial clarity of the original design.

50 Park Road has been recently renovated again to better accommodate the firm's activities, and to further reveal the original spirit of the building's design. Visitors are invited to tour the building, meet members of the staff and examine historical images of the original building and its evolution over time.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Visitors to 50 Park Road will experience the exciting history of a beautifully renovated modern building that has its roots in an architectural design competition in the early 1950s. Come and see the working environment of a leading design firm and meet members of the team who will guide you through the past and present of both the building itself and the work that takes place here.
John C. Parkin, John B. Parkin Associates, 1954

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Royal Canadian Yacht Club's City Clubhouse

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: Royal Canadian Yacht Club was founded in Toronto in 1852 to serve both as a yachting recreational club and an unofficial auxiliary of the Royal Navy in the defence of the waters of Lake Ontario. We are one of Canada’s premier sailing and social clubs, with an emphasis on family participation, the development of our junior sailors, and a Corinthian attitude towards excellence in sailing.

The RCYC operates year round from two facilities: our summer home at the Island Clubhouse and our City Clubhouse in downtown Toronto. This year you are welcome to visit our City home which was built in 1984 on property purchased from the Gooderham family.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Royal Canadian Yacht Club will be offering self-guided tours through the building. Following a short presentation outlining our history guests can tour our building on a self-guided tour that highlights our history, our architecture and our Club.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: First opened in August 1929, the Automotive Building at Exhibition Place was considered a modern marvel. Designed by Douglas Kertland, the Automotive Building was designed in the Art Deco style with intricate stone carvings and spectacular lighting features. Originally constructed for the Canadian National Exhibition to showcase the automobile, the Automotive Building enjoyed a varied history even fulfilling a military role as HMCS York by the Royal Canadian Navy during the Second World War.

Fast forward 80 years from its first opening, the building is now renovated, restored as a stunning conference venue and renamed Allstream Centre. Integral to the renovation is the creation of the largest ballroom in Canada, and meeting space bathed in natural light, creating a link to the surrounding parkland. The exterior of the building has been restored to its 1929 classical glory and many art deco heritage features in the interior showcase its illustrious past.

Officially opened on October 22, 2009 Allstream Centre is the greenest and most energy efficient conference facility in Canada. Targeting LEED Silver designation Allstream Centre is a great asset to Toronto.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Visitors will have the unique opportunity to experience the newly renovated Automotive Building through self guided tours, displays, slideshows and available on site staff. Allstream Centre is not generally open to the public so this a special time to experience the renovation and reminisce about past uses of the building.

textlist.text: What is a planner to do with an obsolete and abandoned brick making factory in the heart of the city? A factory that supplied the bricks to build such iconic landmarks as Casa Loma, Massey Hall, and University of Toronto buildings? Why, build an international showcase for urban sustainability and green design naturally.

Come see how designers and architects have invited nature into the Evergreen Brick Works to build Canada's first large-scale environmental community centre-a national centre for hands-on action that explores how we can create more sustainable cities.
In 2010, Evergreen Brick Works will open its doors featuring:
. a native plant nursery and garden centre
. interactive green design exhibits and interpretive programs
food gardens, farmers' markets, and a year-round Marché featuring local producers.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Walk through history and into the future at Evergreen Brick Works, with behind-the-scenes tours and planet-friendly family activities. Learn about adaptive re-use and green architecture from Evergreen staff and members of the design team on a hart hat tour and catch a glimpse of artist Dan Bergeron installing a photo-based mural. From historic brick making kilns, to graffiti covered walls to a new LEED platinum building inserted into the base of a historic storage facility there's something for everyone. Discover nature's own architects (think birds' nests, bee hives and beaver lodges). Diaspora Dialogues performances Sat. 1 to 4pm Sun 10am to 1pm. Quarry Poems: Witness a permutating line of poetry marching through the quarry. Diaspora Dialogues Tours: Take a literary walking tour of the quarry with Toronto artists as your guide, themes of labour and architecture.

textlist.text: Scarborough Museum buildings depict different time periods in Scarborough’s past.

Cornell House was built in 1858 on the Markham Road in Scarborough Village, and offers a look at rural farm life in Scarborough. Inhabited by descendants of William Cornell for over 80 years, the one and a half storey frame house is typical of Upper Canadian Vernacular Style, and the furnishings derive from Scarborough's early 20th century farming community.

McCowan Log House was built in the north east part of Scarborough on the banks of Wilcott Creek. The simple log structure has a large kitchen with a cooking fireplace and has been restored to its 1850s appearance.

The Kennedy Gallery was an old shed moved from the Kennedy family farm in Agincourt. The interior was renovated using reclaimed tongue and groove pine flooring and hand grained wainscotting salvaged from the Malvern Methodist Church c. 1864 which was demolished in 1976.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Located in beautiful Thomson Memorial Park, this unique site depicts rural life in early Scarborough in a cluster of heritage buildings. Scavenger hunt for kids, food sampling in the heritage kitchens and dramatic vignettes based on Fred Cornell's historic diaries performed by local youth. Guides situated throughout.

entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The PS Trillium was constructed in 1910 at Polson Iron Works in Toronto. The vessel was re-constructed in Port Colborne in 1975 and continues to operate in the same rebuilt condition today. The PS Trillium is the lat remaining side wheeler paddle steamer operating in North America. The vessel is steam powered and operating.

textlist.text: Visitors will meet crew members and be able to discuss the operation of the vessel. Guests will be welcome to photograph and film features of the vessel and crew.
Trillium will be found at the foot of Harbour Square Park at the base of Bay Street. Speak with Toronto historian and author Mike Filey who will be on board both Saturday and Sunday.

entrydata.text: Hugh Garner Housing Co-operative Inc. Green Roof

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: The Hugh Garner Green Roof tops an 8-storey residential building in Cabbagetown, downtown Toronto. The building’s thriving community is home to over 400 residents.

The south green roof spans over 8,000 square feet and features an intensive “wild” garden with a mixture of trees, shrubs and planting beds. The north roof will feature an extensive 14,000 square foot green roof and will be finished in the next year. At 22,000 square feet when completed, it is the largest residential green roof in Canada.

The green roof is fully wheel-chair accessible and includes innovative features such as a storm water retention system that collects rain water to irrigate plants, as well as seating areas shaded by trees and a gazebo. Photovoltaic panels will power the pumps and lighting.

The Hugh Garner Green Roof is part of a larger project to make the building environmentally sustainable. The Co-op is now undergoing an energy retrofit to reduce resource consumption and includes improvements such as solar thermal to preheat water, dual-flush toilets and high-efficiency lighting.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Guided tour of green roof by architect Monica Kuhn including a slide-show of the construction process at Hugh Garner Co-op. Information about alternative energy sources and retrofits for multi-unit residential buildings will be included. Visitors will learn about the Co-op’s namesake, the Depression-era writer, Hugh Garner, and his connection to neighbouring Cabbagetown, where Victorian homes were demolished in the 1970’s to make way for high-rise buildings.

entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Canadian Music Centre’s Chalmers House is a designated heritage building and home to the music of over 750 Canadian composers. The CMC just recently celebrated 25 years in Chalmers House and its own 50th anniversary in 2009. Chalmers House, named in honour of the generous support of the Chalmers family, was originally built in 1892 by Charles J. Hill. The house has a unique Richardsonian style double turret structure to its front facade, the taller of which is capped by special clay tiles imported for Germany and topped by ceramic flame pinnacle. The first floor street-facing windows also show beautiful original stained glass, which is mimicked in modern versions in the large 2nd floor boardroom. While the building interior was renovated by renowned Toronto-based Moriyama and Teshima Architects in 1984, there are still several interior features, including wood work, brick work, stained glass and fireplaces that speak to Chalmers House's original beauty.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Beyond experiencing the architectural elements of Chalmers House, CMC will offer special music programming that showcases the musical talents of our Canadian composers. In the spacious 2nd floor boardroom, CMC will hold an all-day Listening Party using audio recordings and scores of music from its collections connected to the period of Chalmers House's original construction. Visitors can pull up a comfy chair, listen to archival audio recordings, follow along with the musical scores, and experience the sound of Canada's musical heritage.

textlist.text: This is an example of a typical 19th century farmhouse. It is built with red bricks formed on site from the clay in this area. Its corners have a yellow brick interwoven with the red. It is called flemish-bond.
At the turn of the century, early 1900's, the summer kitchen was added and so was the dormer above the front door. The roof is of cedar shakes.

The interior is decorated in furniture from the late 1800's and many of the pieces were donated by our members. Of historic note is that the house is the birthplace of James Shaver Woodsworth, founder of the Co-operative Commonwealth Federation which was a oolitical party that existed before the NDP. While Woodsworth was a Member of Parliament, he forced the government to bring in Old Age Pensions, Family Allowance and Unemployment Insurance.
Today we rent the facility out for parties, wedding ceremonies, meetings and receptions. We are not funded by the government so we keep the house going through rentals.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Visitors will be treated to a tour of the house, exhibits of old farm equipment, and refreshments.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: 401 Richmond Street West is a heritage designated industrial building that was originally constructed for the Macdonald Manufacturing Company from 1899 - 1923. The building operated as a tin lithography factory for much of it's life and this artistic lineage is maintained as it is now home to over 140 artists, cultural producers, and micro-enterprises. The original character and architectural features of the building have been preserved (including over 800 double-hung wood frame windows) while adding more modern and green elements like a 6,500 square foot roof garden and interior courtyard. 401 Richmond was the recipient of an Award of Merit for adaptive re-use of a historic building by Heritage Toronto in 1999.

textlist.text: Guided tours Sat. at 11am and 1pm, Sunday at 1pm.
Tours at 1pm will include a window restoration demonstration by Property Manager Mike Moody.

The roof garden will be open to the public. On-site galleries open on Saturday. Swipe/Built Books Sat. 2pm authors Margaret & Phil Goodfellow in 401 Lounge talking about A Guidebook to Contemporary Architecture in Toronto.

entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Fort York is the birthplace of urban Toronto and home to Canada's largest collection of original War of 1812 buildings. It is part of a 43 acre, heritage conservation district and is all that remains of the original Garrison Reserve. In 1909 the City purchased the Fort from the Federal government, and in 1934 the restored fort was opened as an historic site. The grounds and neighbouring environment encompass remnants of the late 18th-century landscape, part of the 1813 battlefield, 2 military cemeteries, and the largest urban archaeological site in Canada containing deep, stratified and well-preserved archaeological remains both inside and outside the walls. Fort York was captured and destroyed in April 1813 by American forces during the War of 1812. The 7 buildings that exist date from the Fort's reconstruction period late in the War.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Enjoy historical tours of the site, special architectural tours of selected buildings, period demonstrations of musketry, historic cooking and more. This weekend will also showcase a bateau-building project by Scouts Canada-Toronto Council. kid-friendly grounds and many indoor exhibits telling of Toronto and its turbulent military past. Sunday at 1pm walking tour "Fort York and the Garrison Common: Battlefields, Graves and Urban Development"

textlist.text: Established in 1849, the Pape Avenue Cemetery is Toronto’s first Jewish burial site. It is located in the east end of Toronto, on Pape Avenue south of Gerrard, and was established by Toronto Hebrew Congregation, the predecessor to Holy Blossom Temple.

Participants will be exposed to the rich history of this cemetery as well as stories surrounding the ordinary as well as influential individuals who were buried there. The Pape Avenue cemetery hosts some of the most prominent Jewish residents of Toronto from that period. This event will therefore provide a glimpse into early Jewish Toronto history through the lens of one cemetery.

The cemetery is locked up and has been closed to the public, due to security reasons, for many years. This event will provide the public with free and open access to this hidden, historic and sacred site, situated within the heart of East York.

Short tours of the cemetery will be given throughout the course of the day led by Dr. Ellen Scheinberg, Director of the Ontario Jewish Archives, and Susan Brown, local artist and community activist, along with several other OJA volunteers. The tour will examine Jewish burial customs, the history of the early Jewish community, as well as the artistic imagery that is engraved on the gravestones to represent the deceased.
Participants will also have the opportunity to look around, ask questions, and pick up brochures that document the services of the Ontario Jewish Archives and the history of Holy Blossom Temple.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Toronto's first Stock Exchange building was built in 1912 at 234 Bay Street. The Exchange merged in the 1930s with the Standard Stock and Mining Exchange and a new structure was erected on the same site. Designed by architects George and Moorehouse with associate S.H. Maw and completed in 1937 it combines streamlined moderne, art deco and stripped classicism. Revered as an architectural and technological marvel, The Toronto Stock Exchange building was designated a heritage property on August 14, 1978 because of its "architectural value and historic interest." The dominant style of the limestone and pink granite facade is streamlined moderne with its horizontal emphasis on door and window treatments, rounded corners and bands of contrasting stone. Probably the most significant feature of the facade is the frieze at the second floor level. Designed by renowned Canadian artist and muralist Charles Comfort, the frieze, chiseled into the limestone, depicts a renewed and vibrant Canadian economy. Similar images are carved in the stainless steel medallions of the front doors at both the north and south recessed entrances of the building.

George and Moorehouse with associate S.H. Maw, 1937

Coach House Press is located in an old coach house on the U of T campus. It has been the home of the Coach House Printing Company and Coach House Books since 1965. In 2007, fifteen solar panels were installed on the building's roof.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Visitors to Coach House will be treated to a guided tour of the premises, including a history of the printing and publishing trades in Canada. Master printer Stan Bevington, pressmen and publishers will show visitors how books are printed on our two Heidelberg presses, and they'll give a lesson in letterpress printing on our Vandercook. Visitors will also have an opportunity to browse through our bookstore, and to snap a photo of the poem carved into bpNichol Lane. We'll be giving away lots of print souvenirs, too! Sat. 1pm walking tour through Annex neighbourhood with Shawn Micallef – Spacing senior editor, Eye Weekly columnist and author of the new book Stroll: Psychogeographic Walking Tours of Toronto.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: In 1905, a group of Toronto businessmen commissioned a young architect from Hamilton, Ontario - John M. Lyle - to build them “the finest theatre on the continent”. The result was the Royal Alexandra, a masterpiece of beaux-arts design and a jewel-box of fine marble, hand-carved cherry and walnut woods, crystal chandeliers, velvet seats and ornate, gilded plaster. 105 years later. The “Royal Alex” remains an architectural landmark, a beloved Canadian national treasure and one of the most storied theatres in North America.

textlist.text: No backstage access, No performance, No kids'activities

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Gibson House was built in 1851 in the Georgian Revival style of architecture. The house was home to David and Eliza Gibson and their family. David was a local politician, a land surveyor and a farmer. The house is furnished to reflect a family living in rural Willow Dale, yet relatively close to Toronto. Visitors should make note of the gracious front entrance to the house with its fan light transom and side lights, as well as the interesting 'granited' walls and painted floorcloth. The hired man's room is accessible by way of its own staircase, and while comfortable, is furnished differently than the family bedrooms. Mrs. Gibson's kitchen is always bustling with activity and filled with delicious smells. It is almost possible to hear the family as they gather in the parlour, reading, sewing, or perhaps singing along with music played on the beautiful piano.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Great family activities! Costumed interpreters will share the story of the house, the Gibson family and their community. In the Discovery Gallery: Interactive games, activity boxes, dress-up area and weaving for children of all ages.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Zion Schoolhouse, School Section No. 12, York Township, was built in 1869 by the farming families of L'Amaroux. Several generations of these families attended the school until its closure in 1955. Constructed of local red brick, it has subtle decorative details in yellow brick. The north-south orientation with three large nine-over-nine sash windows on the east and west sides allows for a remarkably bright, naturally-lit interior. The Schoolhouse, one of hundreds that used to dot the Ontario landscape, serves as a reminder of our rural past.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Great family experience. Learn about the turn-of-the-century students at S.S. No. 12 as you explore their beautifully restored schoolroom. Write on a slate, or maybe use a steel pen, while sitting in a 1910-schooldesk. Read a story from a 1910 primer. Try some "Edwardian Arithmetic." Play with toys from the period. Create a paper craft to take home. Other Information: Free parking is limited on Trudy Road or Angus Drive. There is also limited parking available in a lot off Angus Drive.

textlist.text: Located in the heart of Toronto’s Discovery District, MaRS works to build global companies from Canada’s leading science and technology. Our approach involves delivering inventive entrepreneurial programming alongside hands-on business-building advice, market research and access to capital – as well as creating an inspiring physical space for the convergence of people and ideas.

Since its doors opened in 2005, the MaRS Centre has rivaled technology clusters worldwide with a stunning 750,000 sq. ft. suite of three linked buildings, including a renovated heritage wing of the venerable Toronto General Hospital and two adjoining modern glass towers. More than 2,000 people come to work at the complex in 65 tenant organizations spanning the innovation spectrum from leading research labs to emerging and mid-size technology companies, multinationals, venture capital and legal firms. The Centre’s soaring glass atrium and tech-ready meeting spaces have also become prized locations for more than 1,100 meetings, conferences and events, drawing in excess of 80,000 visitors.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Tour the state-of-the-art laboratories of the Ontario Institute for Cancer Research. See the Canadian Film Centre Media Lab a unique training, research & production think-tank environment for emerging new media content developers, practitioners and companies. Visit the Lloyd & Dephine Martin Prosperity Institute, the world's leading think-tank on the role of sub-national factors-location, place and city-regions-in global economic prosperity. Meet interesting tenants including MaRS companies in our incubators. The MaRS Centre is a stunning example of how old and new converge to create an inspiring physical space for the collaboration of people and ideas.

entrydata.text: Officially opened in 1893, this impressive Richardsonian Romanesque building is the meeting place of Ontario's Legislative Assembly. entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Toronto’s First Post Office is a small private museum administered by The Town of York Historical Society, situated on its original site and within its original walls. The interior is a recreation based on authentic archival materials discovered still extant from Postmaster James Scott Howard’s original construction in 1833. We are a legally incorporated non-profit organization, members of the Ontario Museum Association, Canadian Museums Association, the Ontario Historical Society, as well as numerous other local historical societies and related organizations.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Dating back to British colonial times, this building is one of few left standing from the old town of York. Seating yourself by the fireplace in its cozy reading room you can write a letter with a quill pen, seal it with wax and, yes, even mail it from the same post office that served the denizens of the city from 1833 to 1839. A scale model of Toronto in 1837 makes this an ideal starting point for any exploration of the area.

textlist.text: 152 years ago, George William Allan(1822-1901) offered a 5 acre oval-shaped parcel of land to the Toronto Horticultural Society. This generous act of private sector philanthropy was a legacy for the citizens of Toronto. In 1902 a fire destroyed the original 1878 Pavillion. The new Palm House was designed by City Architect, Robert McCallum and constructed in 1910.

The design suggests a move toward Modernism at the end of the Victorian era. The steel structure guaranteed that it would last considerably longer than any of its wooden predecessors. Plants from the original Palm House were transfered into the New Palm House in 1910. It should be noted that the Palm House is perhaps the 7th oldest structure of its kind in North America. Additions to the Palm House were made by the Lord and Burnham Greenhouse Company in 1924 and 1957. In 2004, the header house of the former Univeristy of Toronto Research Greenhouse was relocated to Allan Gardens. This greenhouse has become the focus of the Children's garden programme.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Tours of the greenhouses will highlight the history and cultural significance of the site. Also the guides will focus on the importance of plants for food, medicine, building materials and other uses.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Cedar Ridge Creative Centre, originally known as Uplands, was the summer home for the Charles C. Cummings family. Built in the Arts & Crafts style, the 14-room, 5000 square foot mansion was completed in 1912-1913. In addition to the main house, there is a gardener's cottage, stable and attached chauffeur's cottage, now the Carriage House Studio. In 1927, the house was purchased by John Fraser, a Toronto financier, who greatly enhanced the surrounding gardens so much so, that the property was featured in a 1942 edition of Canadian Home and Gardens magazine. In 1978, Cedar Ridge was acquired by the City of Toronto and has operated as a fine arts centre and gallery since that time.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Come and enjoy the beautiful building and lush gardens overlooking the Scarborough Golf and Country Club. Cedar Ridge Creative Centre and Cedar Ridge Studio Gallery in partnership will provide information for tours of the house and gardens.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Toronto's oldest house, Scadding Cabin was built by the Queen's Rangers in 1794 for John Scadding, clerk to Lieutenant-Governor John Graves Simcoe. The one-room cabin is constructed of squared, white pine logs with dovetailed corners. In 1879 the York Pioneer Society moved the cabin from its original site on the east bank of the Don River to its present location at Exhibition Place, an act now recognized as the city's earliest example of architectural preservation. Scadding Cabin is furnished as a typical settler's first house, with artifacts dating from the 1790s to the 1850s. The cabin’s first owner was John Scadding, an assistant to Upper Canada's first Lieutenant Governor, John Graves Simcoe. Scadding’s log home originally sat about where present-day Queen Street crosses the Don Valley. In 1869, a small group of far-sighted men formed the YPHS to preserve the pioneer history of York County, which included Toronto. In 1879, the then owner of the cabin gave it to The Pioneers to preserve.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Enthusiastic Society members maintain the cabin, sell 19th and early 20th century recipes, and happily answer your questions about the early history of York (Toronto). The volunteers are members of one of Canada’s oldest historical groups, The York Pioneer and Historical Society (YPHS). The story of why the cabin sits in the middle of the CNE is entwined with the history of the YPHS and Exhibition Place itself.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Distillery Historic District Scale Tank Loft, Bldg. 61

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Scale Tank Loft sits atop the Pure Spirits complex, a group of physically and functionally linked glass-wood-and-brick structures, probably designed by David Roberts, Jr. and constructed in 1873. Here, alcohol, pumped across Trinity Street from the Stone Distillery, was rectified (purified) in stills located in four narrow buildings along Trinity Street, and then piped to various possible locations for storage and distribution. Given the potentially explosive nature of the process, the Pure Spirits buildings contain large amounts of glass that would blow-out to save the buildings. The architect solved the practical problem with unusual elegance.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: In the usually off-limits Scale Tank Loft, hardy visitors will encounter three extremely rare – perhaps unique – Victorian industrial artifacts: huge platform scales, each capable of weighing 60,000 pounds of alcohol. Located above Building 61, the loft contains three giant copper tanks set on scales manufactured around 1898 by the Fairbanks Company. Here, a single employee performed two vital functions: weighing and blending alcohol. Weighing the liquids was the only way to accurately track the amount of spirits created and transferred. The Loft provides a peak architectural experience, but is accessible only on foot via a staircase entered from Tank House Lane.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Distillery Historic District - Stone Distillery Building 5

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Designed by David Roberts, Sr. and constructed in 1859-60, Gooderham & Worts’ Stone Distillery is the oldest surviving building on the site. Built of Kingston limestone, the building was parallel to the original waterfront and serviced by both lake ships and railway cars passing along what is now Stone House Walk. The Stone Distillery housed three related functions: milling, fermenting and distilling. Built to last, with walls 3 ½ feet thick at the base, the classically proportioned, L-shaped building rises five stories high. Sadly, but not cataclysmically, fire destroyed most of the wooden interior in October 1869. The exterior walls and machinery survived and the distillery was back in business by spring 1870.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Upon entering the 1860s Stone Distillery from the south entrance, visitors are greeted by spectacular four-storey display of industrial heritage artifacts that has been installed just in time for Doors Open. As you move through the space (either on foot or via elevator), inspect the distilling column, control panel, grain chutes and other unusual artifacts, as well as the images and interpretations that conjure up life at Toronto’s – and for a time the world’s – largest distillery. History is also inscribed on the very walls, notably the semi-circular outline of the flywheel housing for the 1882 engine that arcs overhead on the east wall.

entrydata.text: Centre for Addiction and Mental Health Historic Walls

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: In 1860, the southern section of the present CAMH historical wall was built by unpaid patient labourers at the then Provincial Lunatic Asylum, using a design from architect Kivas Tully. These brick barriers surrounded 50 acres of the asylum grounds but the east and west walls had to be torn down and re-built in 1888-89 when portions of land on these sides of the asylum were sold and the grounds were reduced to the present 26 acre site. Deterioration due to pressure from external sources along the northwest wall by the early 21st century led to restoration work in 2007 which has now been completed, in part with the paid work of CAMH clients who were employed for this task.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The CAMH Historical Walls are the perimeter brick structures which were built by unpaid psychiatric patient labourers during the 19th century at the former Asylum for the Insane, Toronto, now the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH). The southern section dates from 1860 and the eastern and western walls date from 1888-89. Guided one hour tours every hour of portions of the wall during which the work and contributions of patients who lived and died behind this structure will be highlighted. These bricks include the oldest physical examples on the southern wall of psychiatric patients' labour from 19th century Ontario which are now 150 years old and are thus of immense historical and architectural value in understanding the lives of a group of people who have been so long subject to discrimination. Etchings carved into these historical walls by asylum inmates, and other unique physical markers representing patients’ history – including bricked in windows and an old railway track – will be spoken about during this tour to highlight the stories this wall has to tell us about the people who lived behind it.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Todmorden Mills was once a thriving industrial community that provided lumber, paper and beer to the growing city of Toronto. Explore two historic millers' homes restored to the mid-19th century and the recently-renovated Papermill Theatre and Galleries. Enjoy guided tours of the Wildflower Preserve, re-naturalized to pre-European contact.

textlist.text: Visitors will have access to the stone cellar of the adobe brick Helliwell House constructed in 1837.

Members of the Todmorden Mills Wildflower Preserve Volunteer Committee will offer guided walks of the natural habitats of Todmorden. The Papermill Theatre will be open to the public on Saturday only as there is an East Side Player's matinee performance on Sunday afternoon. Historic houses are partially accessible due to stairs. The Wildflower Preserve trail is only partially accessible due to stairs.

textlist.text: The heritage timber post and beam building is the former home of MacGregor Socks and presented the opportunity for Stantec to reclaim and transform a piece of the city's industrial history.

Stantec's architects, interior designers and engineers designed a flexible, high-quality workspace that fosters collaboration, innovation, sustainable design excellence and our commitment to city building.

Two incisions were made through the space to create two-storey volumes to connect the space via a public zone featuring reception, meeting rooms, design library and cafés. The internal stairs encourage casual interaction among multi-disciplinary professionals. The studio environment features a low-profile and flexible layout that maximizes daylight and views. A raised floor system offers under floor air, power and data distribution, exposing the beautiful wood structure to emphasize the building’s industrial heritage.

Stantec targeted LEED®CI Gold. The environmental goals are achieved through indirect low wattage task lighting, daylight and occupancy sensors, low flow showers, solar powered faucets, dual flush toilets, use of reclaimed/recycled materials and low VOC finishes.

Visitors will be guided through the space by volunteer architects, designers and engineers. The guides will explain how the space was re-purposed from industrial to studio use. Specifically visitors will better understand the design strategy and how rigorous sustainable goals enrich the space. The tour will be structured with a series of stations where visitors can learn about various sustainable design initiatives such as:
• raised floor systems with air distribution
• use of reclaimed and recycled building materials

Since the tour guides will be professionals working in sustainable design, there will be opportunities for discussion and an informative dialogue about the role of design and construction in our environment.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Museum of Inuit Art, dedicated exclusively to the art and culture of the Inuit, celebrates its third anniversary during Doors Open 2010. Designed by Pat Hanson of gh3 Architects, the museum has won two awards: OAA’s “Design Excellence Award” and Canada Interior’s “Best of Canada Design Competition”. The interior space with white floors, ceilings and angled walls has a spare but strong Arctic aesthetic, reminiscent of snow and icebergs. This tranquil, contemplative environment is ideal for viewing art: sculpture, prints, drawings, ceramics and wall hangings. Recurring themes and regional stylistic differences are highlighted. Especially for Doors Open, is an Inuit dwellings mini-exhibition: the igloo and its construction method, as well as the lesser known summer tupiq or hide tent and the qarmaq or stone and sod house. Fabricated from abundant free material (snow), assembled in as little as an hour and using ingenious construction techniques, the igloo is a perfect building form. Relatively warm inside even when well below zero outside, the igloo was a place of rest and shelter. A larger version, the qaggiq, held community gatherings with games, music and lively entertainment.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Guided Tours of the Museum of Inuit Art will be conducted every two hours: 10 am, 12 pm, 2 pm and 4 pm on Saturday and Sunday. Between tours, visitors can explore the museum at their own pace.

textlist.text: Islamic Foundation of Toronto is one of the oldest Muslim organizations in Canada. It was established in 1969, when an old 3000 square foot building was purchased at Rhodes Avenue and converted into a mosque.

The 2.3 acres land, where the Islamic Center currently stands, was purchased in 1984. It was a giant leap towards the vision of an institution beyond a neighborhood mosque - a center that would provide quality programs in areas of religion, education and social services for the residents of Greater Toronto area and bring them closer.

IFT, for the 6th consecutive year is chosen by the City of Toronto to be showcased to the general public. Over the course of 2 days, approximately 1,500 citizens of Toronto, curious about Islam visit Foundation. They are warmly greeted and escorted to the cafeteria, which is converted into a Bedouin desert-like atmosphere, complete with interactive booths explaining Islam.
Enjoy guided tours, special free of cost printed material for visitors, one of a kind exhibits/presentations and some delicious complimentary snacks.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Union Station is the most magnificent railway terminal ever built in Canada and is Toronto's fourth Union Station, after earlier structures built in 1858, 1873 and 1896. Construction of this Beaux-Arts station was begun during World War I and not completed until 1930. Today, Union Station is the busiest location in Canada, hosting 186 GO trains and 50 VIA trains, with 200,000 people day passing through the facility on a typical weekday. The City of Toronto has begun a revitalization of the station that will result in it becoming one of Toronto's most popular visitor’s destination in addition to its role as Canada's busiest transportation hub.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Archival display of photographs depicting the history of Union Station mounted in the Great Hall. Displays illustrating the City of Toronto's plans for the $640 million revitalization of Union Station as well as GO Transit's plans for rebuilding the historic train shed. Behind-the-scenes tours at 10:30 AM, 12:30 PM and 2:30 PM. Talks on Union Station at 1,2 and 3pm by Lorna Harris, the grand daughter of architect John Lyle.
Ross & Macdonald, Hugh Jones, John M. Lyle, 1915-1920

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Montgomery's Inn, constructed in 1830, is considered to be one of the finest examples of Loyalist or late Georgian architecture in Ontario. The main front door, surrounded by sidelights and overhead fanlight, is typical of this style. Originally the rubble stone exterior of the inn was covered with pebble dashed stucco, with details pointed to resemble proper cut stone, which added to the formal Georgian appearance. In 1967 the stucco was removed. The building's original owner, Irish immigrant Thomas Montgomery operated a successful hotel and tavern here until 1855. Since then, the Inn has fulfilled a variety of community roles such as a residence for tenant farmers and a church and community hall. In 1962, a developer purchased the Inn and sold it to the Etobicoke Historical Society. The Inn opened as a museum in 1975. The interior of the Inn is restored to the period 1847-1850.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: View the CONTACT photography exhibit in the tea room while you enjoy a cup of tea and plate of sweets. If you feel like a walk, nearby Islington Village has many large outdoor murals that depict the early community.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Osgoode Hall opened in 1832 and remains a Toronto landmark and a hub of legal life in Ontario. A fence (1867) renowned for its gates surrounds the property and its beautiful gardens. Highlights include: the Atrium with its geometric tile floor; 19th century courtrooms; the Great Library; the East Wing, the oldest part of the building; and Convocation Hall, better known as the Osgoode Hall Restaurant.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Visit Osgoode Hall at your own pace with our self-guided tour available in English, French and Chinese. Guides will be posted in all the rooms to answer your questions. Bring your camera and have your photo taken in legal robes in one of the courtrooms. There are usually no lineups at Osgoode Hall.

textlist.text: Toronto City Hall is the seat of municipal government and corporate head office for Canada's largest city.
It consists of two office towers. The East Tower has 27 floors; the West Tower, 20. Nestled between the two towers is the Council Chamber where Toronto City Council holds its monthly meetings.
The remainder of the public areas at City Hall are located on the first and second floors. The offices of the Mayor and the 44 City Councillors are on the second floor.

The upper floors of the two towers contain office space for City staff, who provide a wide variety of municipal services to the people of Toronto. Among the staff located at City Hall are the City Manager and the department heads.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Self-guided tours of the Rotunda, Council Chambers, 2nd floor and Observation Deck.

textlist.text: Old City Hall is designed in the Romanesque Revival style. Lennox's design created one of the most magnificent buildings on the North American continent at the time. Built mostly out of Credit Valley Stone, the castle-like plan includes corner pavilions, monumental round-arch openings, an interior courtyard and elaborate decoration inspired by the middle ages. Apparently, without consent, Lennox incorporated his name in the stonework; beginning on the west (Bay Street) wall and extending around the building, the letters E.J. LENNOX ARCHITECT A.D. 1898, are inscribed in the corbels under the roof. The cenotaph, unveiled outside the Queen Street entrance in 1925, was the site of many important civic celebrations, including those marking the end of the Second World War.

The two-story entrance hall was once called "Toronto's grandest indoor space". The hall, originally used for public events, is lined top and bottom with scagliola (faux marble) columns with plaster capitals. The mosaic floor was patterned in Buffalo and brought to Toronto. Lennox's eye for detail even extended to the door knobs that bear the city's old Coat of Arms
self guided tours of the building exterior, grand staircase and landing as well as courtroom 121which was the former Council Chamber.

Opposite the entrance, along the north side of the entrance hall, the Grand Staircase rises to the second floor. On the landing where the stairs divide into two, a monumental stained glass window depicts the Union of Commerce and Industry, and symbolizes the progress of Toronto. The window, manfactured by Robert McCausland Limited, is organized in three arches. The window includes 12 life-size figures, scenes of the Toronto waterfront, depictions of Toronto's second City Hall on Front Street East and Old City Hall. A marble war memorial is positioned beneath the window. The memorial was dedicated to citizens who lost their lives during the Second World War.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Market Gallery is located inside the South St. Lawrence Market on the second floor, and occupies the 19th century civic council chamber, the only remaining section of Toronto's original City Hall (1845-1899)which once stood on this Front Street site. Today, incorporated into the south market building can be found the original centre block facade of Toronto's municipal building, built of contrasting red brick and white stone in the Georgian tradition. Police Station # 1 and its jail, offices and commercial businesses were also located in this building that once had three floors and wings extending back to the shoreline at The Esplanade. Since 1901 when the large barn-style roof was built and the wings were torn down, the South St. Lawrence Market has been a popular destination to shop for fruit, meat, vegetables and cheese. The Market Gallery offers a program of changing exhibitions on Toronto's art, culture and history, plus education programs geared to curriculum and ESL students.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The Market Gallery will offer behind-the-scenes tours of the fine art vault on the 3rd floor featuring the City of Toronto's art collection in conjunction with special talks on the history of the building and neighbourhood in the gallery. Talks will take approximately 40 minutes and will commence on the hour from 10 am - 2 pm.

entrydata.text: John St. Roundhouse - Steam Whistle Brewing

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The CPR John Street Roundhouse, stunning home of Steam Whistle Brewing, is located steps from the CN Tower. Built in 1929, The Roundhouse originally serviced over 50 locomotives a day from Union Station. At its centre, a rotating turntable moved trains into bays for repair. The Roundhouse was the first to use a new clean air and energy conservation system, called "the direct steaming system", which improved train maintenance, fuel consumption and working conditions. Over the decades passenger rail service declined and the facility closed in 1988. In 1999, Steam Whistle Brewing breathed new life into the building, renovating with an eye to preserve the original post and beam construction. The brewery opened its doors to the public as part of Doors Open Toronto 2000. Inside are the Brewery's manufacturing facilities as well as a retail store/gallery and events venue. The building’s exterior walls are almost entirely made up of multi-paned windows, filling the vaulted 30 ft. interior with natural light. The original Douglas Fir posts support the sloped cedar roof. Throughout The Roundhouse, catwalks and exposed brick retain the feel of the building's original use.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Free brewery tours are offered every quarter hour and include a sample of Steam Whistle, Canada's Premium Pilsner. Tours will highlight the building's historic use as a rail facility and its adaptive re-use as a brewery and event venue. Green features of this Building and green initiatives will be highlighted. The Toronto Railway Historical Association will host Doors Open Toronto at the Roundhouse. TRHA volunteers will be available to answer questions and interpret the artifacts. Steam Whistle Brewing's architect, Dave Taylor of Ware Malcolm, will make a presentation on Saturday afternoon at noon and 1pm on the design process of creating a brewery in a historic industrial building. Refreshments for sale and musical entertainment on the brewery’s patio.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Fisher Library comprises the south tower of the Robarts Library complex. The interior is one of the most impressive and dramatic sights in the University, with five mezzanine floors of rare books surrounding an exhibition area. It is named in honour of Thomas Fisher who came from Yorkshire to Upper Canada in 1821 and settled by the Humber River. There he operated a grist mill, and played an active role in the public life of the community. In 1973 his great-grandsons, Sidney and Charles Fisher, donated to the Library their own collections of Shakespeare, various twentieth century authors, and the etchings of the seventeenth century Bohemian artist, Wenceslaus Hollar. Since that time the Library has grown to approximately 700,000 volumes and 3000 linear metres of manuscript holdings and reflects the wide diversity of research conducted at the University of Toronto. Chronologically, the range is from a 1789 B.C. Babylonian cuneiform tablet from Ur, to original drafts and printed works of contemporary Canadian writers such as Margaret Atwood.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The Library will feature an exhibition of Chinese rare books, entitled, Leaves of Enchantment, Bones of Inspiration: The Dawn of Chinese Studies in Canada. The books on display are drawn from the Mu Collection, one of the major Chinese rare book collections in North America, spanning the period from the Song Dynasty (960-1279) to the Qing Dynasty (1644-1911). It originally formed the personal library of a Chinese scholar, Mu Xuexun (1880-1929). In 1933, it was purchased by the Canadian missionary, Bishop William Charles White and then shipped to Toronto in 1935. The exhibition will highlight the treasures of the collection with a broad coverage of subject areas. The long and rich history of Chinese writing and book culture will be vividly illustrated along with related artifacts from the ROM.
Mathers and Haldenby, Toronto, with Warner, Burns, Toan and Lunde, New York, 1973

textlist.text: Levitt Goodman Architects Ltd. is an award-winning architecture firm founded in 1989.

The firm has a proven commitment to providing excellent buildings with a high degree of design expertise. We have received recognition for our architectural work in many forums such as the prestigious Governor General's Medal of Excellence in Architecture, several DX Design Effectiveness Awards, CMHC Best Housing Practices Awards and Urban Institute “Brownie” Awards.
Our designs celebrate the many ways to live and work.
The challenges unique to each project are an opportunity to innovate, to be inspired and to demonstrate how good design improves people's lives.
Collaboration is fundamental to our process.
We feel it is essential to generate ideas and work through problems together - in our studio, with our engineers, contractors and, most importantly, with our clients.
We never lose sight of the context.
We know that buildings are part of a bigger picture - socially, environmentally and culturally - and aim to make each design progressive, sensitive and relevant.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: St. Thomas's Church, a beautiful "Arts and Crafts" building designed by parishioner and renowned Toronto architect Eden Smith, houses a number of architectural treasures, including beautiful historical stained glass windows, a First World War memorial baptistery, and a stunning reredos behind the high altar displaying hand-carved statues of nine saints associated with the parish’s growth and role in the Anglican Church in Toronto. St. Thomas's also has a wonderful collection of treasured church vestments and vessels. Constructed in red brick in 1892-93, and intended to be a temporary structure until the parish could afford a larger stone building, the church has now served the community for 117 years!

textlist.text: Enjoy a self-guided tour, with written information sheets, or allow our knowledgeable volunteers to guide you through this beautiful Eden Smith building.
On Sunday, May 30, 2010 at 3:00 p.m., renowned Parish Organist and Choirmaster, John Tuttle will provide an organ demonstration.

In 2006, a parish garden was created behind the church buildings to preserve green space in our neighbourhood. It features heritage plant varieties not commonly found in residential gardens and provides an economical source of fresh, nutritious food for our community food program Out of the Heat. You will visit our parish garden on your way to or from visiting our neighbours at Coach House Press.

textlist.text: The style of the church is Romanesque Revival. The architect called its design Norman Scottish and it is referred to in mostliterature as an example of Norman Romanesque architecture. The Norman influence is particularly evident in the finely detailed carved stone arched entrance and the Rose window above it. Norman French influence is to be seen in the carved detail of the facade. POlished granite columns at all the main entrances have carved stone caps and bases.The Scottish influence is apparentin the stepped gables of the West Tower and the corner turrets.Note the gargoyles under the eaves on the east side and the words "St. Andrew's" and the date "1875"under the eaves on the Simcoe Street side of the church.
In the interior, items of special interest are:
-the polished cherry wood pews with their carved ends and flower motif
-remembrances of the 48th Highlanders-the memorial window,the regimental colours hanging in the Chancel,the Communion Table with the Book of Remembrance contributed by the Sergent's Mess
-The Gallery organ built by Karl Wilhelm and the Rose window behind it

textlist.text: The history of the naval reserve in Toronto dates to the establishment of a Royal Canadian Navy Volunteer Reserve Half Company in the city of Toronto on April 10, 1923. At the outbreak of WWII, the unit was moved to the Automotive Building on the grounds of the Canadian National Exhibition and in 1942, was commissioned as Her Majesty's Canadian Ship YORK (HMCS YORK) in recognition of local history. During WWII, YORK distinguished itself as one of the premiere naval recruiting depots in the British Commonwealth; almost 17,000 men and women joined the Navy at YORK. HMCS YORK moved to its current location in 1947. The first Naval Reserve air squadron, VC 920, was formed at YORK in 1953 and continued as part of YORK's establishment until being disbanded in 1963. This squadron was equipped with Avengers and had the distinction of being the only Naval Reserve air squadron to achieve carrier qualification.

Today, HMCS YORK has on-strength approximately 248 Officers and Non-Commissioned Members; many serve on full-time service at Naval Reserve Headquarters, QC, on both coasts, and at CFB Borden, ON. The ship's company is diverse and reflects the cultural diversity of Toronto.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Visitors are invited to explore the Canadian Navy from an inside perspective on its 100th anniversary! Historical displays will give visitors an understanding of the naval tradition in Toronto, from its inception in 1923 and its move to the grounds of the CNE in 1942, to its current location at 659 Lakeshore Blvd, in 1947. Visitors will also experience each of the different trades and handle some of the equipment vital to current military operations. Try your hand in the operations room on a ship's bridge simulator, don ship’s fire-fighting gear and hoses, or explore the small craft used for boatswains training. The Royal Canadian Sea Cadet Corps VANGUARD will be displaying its sail boats, which are used for teaching local youth to sail, and 618 Air Cadet Squadron will have its glider on display. The HMCS YORK band will also be performing. The two Cadet corps housed at YORK, RCSCC VANDGUARD and 618 Air Squadron, will have interactive displays appropriate for youth (ages 12-18). Refreshments will be available for purchase in the messes and parking is free.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Campbell House was built in 1822 for Sir William Campbell, the sixth Chief Justice of Upper Canada, and his wife Lady Hannah. It originally overlooked the harbour from high ground at Frederick and Adelaide streets. Threatened with demolition, the 300-ton house was moved to its current site in 1972. Campbell House is the last remaining brick home from the town of York and a fine example of Georgian architecture. Restored to 1830s elegance, it interprets the social and cultural life of the town of York.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Visitors will enjoy the garden and take a self-guided tour of the house. Rare and valuable historical artifacts augment the upper-class domestic setting of the house, furnished in Georgian style. Also on display is an exquisitely detailed model of the town of York in 1825. Sherrill Girard's watercolours will be on display in our gallery. Tafelmusik performance on Saturday at 10:30 and 11:30am

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: CHAPEL OF ST. JAMES-THE-LESS In its vigorous, harmonious composition, this small funeral chapel is a splendid example of High Victorian Gothic design. Its sense of strength and spirituality is derived from the subtle contrast of its stone walls, enveloping roofs, and soaring spire. The chapel was erected in 1860 to plans by Cumberland and Storm, one of Toronto's leading 19th-century architectural firms. Situated on a slight rise, St. James is enhanced by the picturesque setting of its cemetery, which was opened in 1844 and is the oldest established cemetery in the city.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Guided tours of the Chapel and cemetery available. We will visit approximately 20 historic burial sites on the tour.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Sunnyside Beach Juried Art Show & Sale returns to Toronto's historic Sunnyside Pavilion with its annual three-day art event. The building opens its doors to over 80 dynamic emerging and established artists and showcases painting, drawing, photography and sculpture exhibits alongside music and art performances and installations. The hustle and bustle of the "Sunnyside Amusement Beach" (what the area was once called) echoes across the large, open spaces of the pavilion's second floor, usually off limits to the public. The view is amazing: graceful, white arches frame the deep blue of lake Ontario on the horizon. This year's theme of ARCHITECTURE IN ART inspired many attractions including edible sculptures to be featured on the opening night. This is a rare opportunity to experience one of the city's hidden gems under the cultural veil of the Sunnyside Beach Juried Art Show & Sale. For more information, please visit artinitiatives.ca

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The building opens its doors to over 80 dynamic emerging and established artists and showcases painting, drawing, photography and sculpture exhibits alongside music and art performances and installations. The hustle and bustle of the "Sunnyside Amusement Beach" (what the area was once called) echoes across the large, open spaces of the pavilion's second floor, usually off limits to the public. The view is amazing: graceful, white arches frame the deep blue of lake Ontario on the horizon.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Inside the Colonnade, a Brutalist architectural landmark of Toronto’s 1960s, where theatres and museums used to exist, an elegant facility designed by Yabu/Pushelberg has been providing a welcoming space for public encounters with a variety of aspects of Japanese culture since 1995. Inspired by Japanese handcraft and traditional interiors, this cultural venue is far beyond a mere cultural centre. Waving walls and lights coming through squares and circles create a whimsical, gentle atmosphere.

textlist.text: The public lending library at the Japan Foundation, Toronto offers a wide array of resources and services for anyone interested in Japan and Japanese culture. With more than 17,000 Japan-related print and audiovisual materials in English, Japanese and French, the JFT Library’s diverse collection ranges from classical works of literature to a new Manga collection with more than 1000 contemporary Japanese comic books. Materials including Japanese language study materials, CDs, and nonfiction works are also available for circulation. Visitors are welcome to study in the library, browse our collection of Japanese magazines and newspapers, or watch DVDs and videos at one of the four viewing stations.

Behind the library, a gallery space houses "Tenugui Towel: Design Excellence in Japanese Daily Life." These multi-purpose traditional cloths showcase a wide range of designs and themes. With over 200 printed towels on display, this colourful exhibition demonstrates the endless creativity in Tenugui.

entrydata.text: Gerald Robinson and Tampold Wells Architects, 1963

entrydata.text: Bay and Bloor/Bay and Avenue Road

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: After being welcomed to the Museum by our visitor service team, you will proceed to the galleries located on the 2nd and 3rd floors of our facility, situated in the base of a 26 storey complex. Touring the Museum takes approximately 60 minutes. Allocating 1 1/2 hours for a visit should suffice, in order to allow time for casual touring and a visit to the Museum Shop.

textlist.text: The Textile Museum of Canada is one of Toronto’s most engaging visual arts organizations. With more than 12,000 objects from more than 200 countries and regions, the TMC’s permanent collection celebrates cultural diversity and includes traditional fabrics, garments, carpets and related artifacts such as beadwork and basketry. The Museum offers a broad variety of exhibitions including themed shows based on our permanent collection and contemporary exhibitions of the work of Canadian and international artists. Visit fibrespace, our permanent hands-on gallery to touch and explore the properties of cloth and see the endless possibilities of pattern and decoration.
Artists Lia Cook, David R Harper and Stephen Schofield examine themes of portraiture and human identity through textiles.
Fashionably Wrapped: The Influence of Kashmir Shawls
This exhibition presents examples of exuberantly beautiful shawls, details this garment’s shape, style and symbolism throughout history.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Arts and Letters Club of Toronto, The

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: The St George's Hall at 14 Elm Street is a Toronto landmark — a building with a lively history of remarkable colour and vivacity. The building was built by the St. George's Society in 1891 in a faux- gothic style. It has been designated a building of National Historic Significance by the Government of Canada.

The focus of The Arts & Letters Club life and activity is The Great Hall, a splendid room with a cathedral ceiling, a large fireplace, a choir gallery, a well-equipped stage, and wonderfully tongue-in-cheek banners by J.E.H. MacDonald celebrating the names of illustrious early Members. The present form was created by member architects Henry Sproatt and Ernest Rolph shortly after the building was leased by the Club in 1920.

Adjoining the Great Hall is a comfortable lounge and bar. The LAMPS room across the hall is decorated with objects celebrating club artists, architects, actors, musicians and writers. The hallways and meeting rooms are treasure-troves of Club memorabilia. The visual artists use the third floor Studio for painting sessions.
After purchasing the building in 1986, The Arts and Letters Club undertook extensive renovations to restore the building.
The Arts & Letters Club of Toronto occupies St. George’s Hall built in 1891 to the design of architects Robert J. Edwards and Hiram J. Webster.

Self guided tours of the building will be available with detailed explanation of the features by Club members. View the permanent collection which includes several Group of Seven paintings and a wide range of art spanning more than a century. In the lounge you will have a unique glimpse into the history of graphic art in Canada in the form of the annual lists of club executive since the founding in 1908.
The Great Hall will feature exhibits of the work of member architects past and present in keeping with the theme of Doors Open Toronto 2010: Architecture.

entrydata.text: Robert J. Edwards and Hiram J. Webster, 1891

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: U of T Scarborough - Science Research Building

textlist.text: The Science Research Building, designed by Moriyama & Teshima Architects, is state-of-the-art for establishing research clusters in a more open concept setting than is historically used in science buildings. The design brings together experts who share common interests and technology to permit new levels of interaction and encourage interdisciplinary collaboration.
The 6,080 square metre Science Research Building is home to 16 principal investigators and their research staff of graduate students and postdoctoral fellows.

On the first floor researchers examine the impact of the physical and social environment on brain function and response. The second floor is directed toward the study of plant form and function, with the ultimate aim of improving crop productivity and value. Researchers on the third floor are using sophisticated technologies to identify, track and assess the impact of dangerous contaminants in the environment.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Guest will have the opportunity to tour the Science Research Building on all floors. There will be information packages provided to allow for a more comprehensive understanding of what each space is used for.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: U of T Scarborough - Student Centre

textlist.text: Designed by Stephen Phillips and Tom Kyle of Dunlop Architects Inc., the Student Centre is a window on student initiatives, leadership and activities on campus. With its striking form, transparency and continuity between indoor and outdoor spaces, the building creates a commanding new entrance to the UTSC campus.

The building’s architectural highlights include the great cantilever over the main entrance, titanium cladding, recycled structural steel purchased from the Royal Ontario Museum, a soaring atrium and two elegant courtyards.

The Student Centre is a green building, designed to meet the Silver standard for LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design, a rigorous U.S. and Canadian standard for energy efficient and sustainable buildings). Some of its innovative features include a green roof to reduce energy demand; sustainable-source building materials, such as bamboo floors in the lounges and dining areas; an expanded campus bus stop to promote transit use and an irrigation system that recycles rainwater.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Guest will have the opportunity to tour the Student Centre on all floors. There will be information packages provided to allow for a more comprehensive understanding of what each space is used for.

entrydata.text: U of T Scarborough - Arts & Administration Building

textlist.text: Painting, sculpture, dance, drama, music and performance art have a new venue within the Arts and Administration Building at the University of Toronto Scarborough (UTSC).

The $20-million facility features classrooms, studios for fine art and music and a 300-seat lecture theatre. Graduate art studio support the university’s tri-campus master’s program in visual studies.

Designed by Montgomery Sisam Architects Inc., the 5,530 square metre /60,000 square foot, four-storey centre features leading-edge energy efficiency and environmental design. A new campus Welcome Centre has been provided as well as offices for the registrar, faculty and staff.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: History of the church dates back to 1797, while the design for the present Gothic Revival Cathedral was won by Frederic Cumberland after an international competition following the disastrous fire of 1849. Built of local brick and Ohio stone, it opened for services in 1853, and tower completed in 1874. It is the highest church tower in Canada, and houses a peal of twelve change-ringing bells. Chancel ceiling of gold leaf by Gustav Hahn. Stained glass windows from Canada, England Germany and the United States. Memorials date back to those who fought in the American Revolutionary War.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Tours of the Cathedral and a series of short organ concerts will be offered throughout both Saturday and Sunday, along with opportunities to talk to the organist about the instrument. Tours up the tower to see the change-ringing bells will be offered all day Saturday only. Children from age 5 and up must be accompanied by an adult if going up the tower. Visitors are invited to attend the 4:30pm Evensong Service on Sunday. A choice of scavenger hunts will be offered to children. There will be an exhibit on view re the renovations occuring in the adjoining Parish House. **CHURCH CLOSED TO DOORS OPEN TORONTO VISITORS FROM 10:45AM UNTIL NOON FOR A FUNERAL.

entrydata.text: U of T Scarborough - Management Building

textlist.text: The Department of Management is closely connected to the business community thorough co-op education. Combining classroom theory with relevant employment experience, students gain the knowledge and skills needed to compete in today’s global economy.

Designed by Kuwabara Payne McKenna Blumberg Architects Inc. (KPMB), the 47,000 square foot (4385 sq. metres) Management Building features a spectacular atrium, specially designed case rooms, interview rooms, offices for faculty and staff, study spaces, and a resource room for management co-op students. The tiered, horseshoe-shaped caserooms are particularly well suited to management course instruction.

entrydata.text: U of T Scarborough - John Andrews Buildings

textlist.text: The original Scarborough College - Humanities and Sciences Wings 1965. The most famous piece of architecture is the main academic building designed by John Andrews. It is a massive, poured-concrete, internally connected, linear structure that stretches for a kilometer along the rim of Highland Creek valley. It was opened to international acclaim and still features in many architectural textbooks as a pre-eminent example of a modernist "mega-structure".
Wide and high walkways overlooked by balconies run the length of the Humanities and Sciences Wings. They converge at the Meeting Place, the town square of the university.
The oldest buildings within the campus are still heavily used by students, faculty and staff for lectures, office space, meeting room and special events.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper

entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The oldest sugar company in Canada (founded in 1854) Redpath Sugar constructed its Toronto production centre between 1957-59. The refinery was the first industrial facility constructed in Ontario to coincide with the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway in 1959. As well as being designed with functionality and efficiency in mind, it also has a singular geometric appearance as it consists of a cluster of cubic, cylyndrical and triangular-shaped buildings, most constructed with a steel girder lattice, covered by a specially-produced white glazed brickwork. In addition, the buildings are all connected by a dramatic series of spans that are in fact angled conveyor belt tunnels that transport the product through the process system of the refinery without exposing it to the elements. Decorating the north face of the Raw Sugar Shed is one of a world-wide series of murals by the marine artist Wyland.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Located on the Toronto waterfront, the Redpath Sugar Refinery tour consists of a guided tour pointing out the several elements of the refinery's on-going operations, including: the Bag Storage Warehouse, the Raw Sugar Shed, the Redpath Sugar Museum, main loading areas for bulk deliveries, Powerhouse, Process and Packaging. NB due to governmental regulations, access to the interior of some of these structures is not allowed and a video virtual-tour is presented instead.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Gladstone Hotel is the oldest continuously operating hotel in Toronto. It was originally built in 1889 as a stylish hostelry across from the then existing Parkdale railroad station. It was designed by George Miller, the architect of the Lillian Massey building of the University of Toronto, in red brick with beautiful sandstone carvings. The location of the Gladstone Hotel, just east of Dufferin on Queen Street West, was one considered the western edge of Toronto and it provided accommodations to travelers from the Parkdale train station as well as visitors and exhibitors at the Canadian National Exhibition.The Gladstone Hotel has been described as an example of “unabashed architectural exuberance” utilizing details from the Greek, Romanesque, Gothic and Renaissance eras. The building was purchased by the Zeidler family in 2002 from the previous owner who had handled operations since 1964. The hotel was restored over a two year period to reflect the building’s architectural history.

textlist.text: Guided tours will be offered at 11:30 am, 1:30 pm and 3 pm on both days. Tour Guides: Christina Zeidler, Jeremy Vandermeij. Talk with the Restoration Specialists: John Wilcox, Douglas Roberts and Ray Karu
Exact times of the talks will be posted on the Gladstone website www.gladstonehotel.com
John Wilcox, heritage glazier, specializes in heritage glass and glass restoration.

Douglas Roberts, heritage woodwork specialist, specializes in the restoration and recreation of heritage woodwork. Ray Karu, specializes in the restoration of interior woodwork as well as faux finishes, especially wood graining. Allan Saunder, who specializes in historic window recreation. These folks were instrumental in the physical restoration of the Gladstone Hotel as an important Toronto landmark and fully functioning hotel. They will be giving brief explanations and demonstrations of their processes.
