entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Gilda's Club Greater Toronto - the Lombard Street Firehall

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: Affectionately known as the Old Fire hall for its first use, The Lombard Street Fire hall was designed by David Roberts, built in 1886 and added to in 1895 of brown sandstone with red brick facades. The building served as the Central Fire Station until 1969 when it combined with the Berkley Fire Station to become the Front Street Station.
Second City began operation in March of 1974 and hosted Comedy until their move to Blue Jays Way in 1997.
The newly formed Gilda’s Club Greater Toronto was looking for a home – what better place than the building that that gave Gilda a Toronto home for her innovative comedy.

Working with Kimberley Seldon, many designers donated their expertise to convert the theatre into the wonderful homelike space it is today. All of the furnishings and artwork were donated as well. The main floor consists of the Community Room, the adjoining Living Room and nearby Teen Hangout [with pool table]. The second floor is devoted the library, support groups, the Art Program and Noogieland our special place for children.
Gilda’s Club opened the signature red doors in October, 2001 and has provided cancer support to the whole family since that time.
Join with staff and volunteers to see the third re-creation of the Lombard Street Fire Hall.
• Walk down memory lane to a time when fire hoses were hung off the tower to dry and horses were the fire engines
• Learn about Gilda Radner - See a video of her comedy act
• Explore Gilda’s Club Greater Toronto and discover how the design and atmosphere of the Club House helps those touched by cancer – men, women and children, their friends and loved ones.
• See the many pieces of original Art donated by local artists and art lovers.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Mackenzie House, a Greek revival rowhouse built in 1858, is now an historic house museum restored to reflect the genteel middle-class poverty of William Lyon Mackenzie and his family from 1859 to 1871. Mackenzie was Toronto's first mayor, an activist journalist and a reform politician, and he became the leader of the 1837 Rebellion. The museum also has a recreated mid-19th century printshop.

textlist.text: Come and visit the home of Toronto's first Mayor, and one of the City's earliest activist journalists!

This weekend only we invite Doors Open participants to enter through the historic front door, just as the Mackenzie Family's guests would have done. View the exhibit "Toronto's Tumultuous Year: William Lyon Mackenzie as Mayor."

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Greenwood Shop is part of the 31 acre Greenwood complex which opened in March 1960. The shop covers approximately 190,000 square feet and is the workplace of almost 200 employees. Work performed includes major vehicle overhauls and component rebuilds to support the fleet of subway vehicles for the B-D, Y-U-S, Sheppard subway lines as well as the SRT system. The shop also maintains the TTC's fleet of workcars that are used in the maintenance of subway tracks, tunnels and wayside equipment.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Behind the scenes tour featuring machinery and equipment used in the overhaul and repair of big subway cars and workcars used by the TTC.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: This Animal shelter is two stories tall. First floor includes a welcoming reception area complete with a cat playroom and sitting area. On the second floor the ceiling and lighting maintain and highlight the architectural history of the Horse Palace. This floor also includes a dog play area, rabbit and rodent room and provides an enriched environment that benefits the animals well being and gives prospective adopters a place to get to know their future pet.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Self paced tours of Toronto's newest multilevel animal shelter. Meet our Animal Services staff and many furry friends, ask questions about our shelter and adoptable pets. Bring your camera and meet K9 Cody & Robert for demonstrations, tips and the opportunity to pet Cody. Perhaps you may adopt a new best friend.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Nestled in Toronto's Discovery District, The Michener Institute is a 15-storey building on the corner of St. Patrick and Elm Streets that began a retro-fit in 2009 with the intention of creating a LEEDs certified educational institute. The retro-fit will see the building retain its practicality for educating medical technologists, therapists and practitioners, but will expand on spaces to enable greater interprofessional collaboration and team-based simulations. Phase 1 of the building redevelopment has been completed and is represented in Doors Open by the LEED certified CAE/Michener Centre for Excellence in Simulation and Innovation.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: At Michener you will see how simulation education works and maybe even participate in a simulation yourself! Tour the brand new state-of-the-art CAE/Michener Centre for Excellence in Simulation and Innovation and see how medical technologists, practitioners and therapists learn to be the best in the biz. Throughout the Centre there will be many different displays and simulation exercises to educate and entertain Doors Open participants. Come and learn a more about our programs, including nuclear medicine, genetics technology, and respiratory therapy, and see how we are educating the next generation of health care heroes.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Metropolitan United Church began in 1818 in what is now the commercial heart of Toronto. The first building was a small Methodist chapel located on nearby King Street. Membership grew, along with population, so in 1831 the Newgate Methodist Episcopal Church, 1833, to accommodate 1,000 people.In 1868 the Methodist Church constructed Metropolitan Wesleyan Methodist Church, which was dedicated in 1872. The building seated 2,300 and was described as Canada's "cathedral of Methodism." The United Church of Canada was formed in 1925 by the union of Methodist and Congregational and two-thirds of the Presbyterian churches in Canada. Metropolitan Wesleyan Methodist became Metropolitan United and was chosen as the site of the first General Council of the United Church. In 1928 fire destroyed the church building the congregation commissioned a redesigned structure The largest organ in Canada, built by Casavant Freres in Quebec, was installed first played in 1930. The organ has 8,233 pipes.

textlist.text: Icon Display in the Founders Chapel

textlist.text: Since its construction in 1931, the Horse Palace has remained one of the finest Art Deco Buildings in the City of Toronto and possibly in the province or nation.
Between 2004 and 2006, Exhibition Place constructed a Green Roof on the historic Horse Palace including a "meadow" and a 100 kilowatt pilot Solar Photovoltaic Power Generation Plant.

entrydata.text: Apart from activities downstairs offered by the Mounted Unit, Animal Services and the Riding Academy, we will offer tours of the Horse Palace's Green Roof (a "meadow" and the photovoltaic power generation plant). Staff from the Operations Division of Exhibition Place will be on hand to explain the science behind these intiatives.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: This four-storey building includes a re-developed and smaller Bethel Baptist Church on grade, plus common room and nineteen "Life-Lease Apartments” for seniors, plus parking underground for 26 cars. Sponsored by Bethel Baptist Church, which has existed on this site since 1920, this 4 year-old energy-efficient building is an excellent example of a new intensified use of an inner city site. It was specifically designed for "independent” seniors over 65 to age-in-place surrounded by a caring community of other seniors and neighbourhood families. Most importantly it allows a well established community institution (the Church) to continue with greatly reduced overhead while local seniors can remain residing in the neighbourhood where they raised their families and living without the worry and financial stress of owning a larger residential house.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: See the beauty of the re-established Church where beloved elements such as the stain glass windows, alter and wood panelling were re-installed in the new Church space. Meet the seniors who live in this building and visit several apartments. Learn details about the project by reading the storyboards on display. Watch the slide show documenting the history of the development process as led by this volunteer group. Many of our residents will tell you that they were never going to move from their homes when what they really wanted was to stay in the neighbourhood. Most of them didn’t need to change where they bank, or shop for food, or get their hair done. You will be quite taken with the modern designs of many of the apartments. Who thought that mother would thrive in an open-concept kitchen with views over neighbourhood homes and gardens. Come see what community-based action can achieve!

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Exhibition Place - Horse Palace - Mounted Unit

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Horse Palace has been described as one of the finest Art Deco Buildings in the City of Toronto and possibly in the province or nation. Art Deco elements of the Horse Palace include a hard-edged angular composition, cubist forms and strong horizontal and vertical planes. The low relief sculptured friezes of horses located on the exterior of the building are also indicative of the Art Deco style of design. In addition, details such as lanterns, skilfully executed in coloured glass, accentuate the overall architectural design of the building. When constructed in 1931, the Horse Palace was billed as one of the finest equestrian facilities in Canada and continues to fulfil its traditional role during the annual Canadian National Exhibition and the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Free horse-drawn wagon rides,stable tours including a meet-and-greet with the horses and officers of the Toronto Police Mounted Unit, riding demonstration of crowd-control manoeuvres by the Toronto Police Mounted Unit,presentation of syncronized riding skills by The Governor General's Horse Guards,Mini Cooper, the smartest and smallest equine at The Riding Academy entertains audiences, life-size electronic Equine Simulators walk, trot and canter like the real thing, vintage photo gallery of the important role of horses is depicted in Toronto-History & Horses.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Built in 1913 in a style which has been described as Queen Anne Revival, Arts & Crafts, and Edwardian, this grand red brick house is profiled by a large L-shaped wrap-around verandah with stylized Doric columns. Significant white oak interior features with the centre hall plan, a vestibule door with bevelled leaded glass, a large leaded art glass window which lights the landing of the main staircase, panelled doors and wainscotting, strip hardwood floors and radiators. In 1933, The Ontario Historical Society (OHS) entered into a partnership with the former City of North York to preserve and restore the John McKenzie House including the milk house, stable and coach house. The John McKenzie House serves as the provincial headquarters of the OHS.

textlist.text: Vistors can hear the history of the house which was slated for demolition in the early 1990s, ultimately saved and restored by the Ontario Historical Society with the support from local residents. They may also hear some history about the house and its construction and some history about Willowdale.

As the headquarters of The Ontario Historical Society, the John McKenzie House will also offer some insight into how a not-for-profit historical organization is working across Ontario to protect and preserve our natural and built heritage.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Kasian Architects - 85 Hanna Avenue, Liberty Village

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Kasian, an architecture, interior design, and planning firm designed this 17,000 sq. ft. Toronto office located in the heart of Liberty Village. The building was completed in 2006, but design of the third floor Kasian office was completed in August 2007. Led by Kasian's own interior design team, the space was conceived as a working lab to embody best practices, show theory in action, serve as a benchmark for clients’ corporate offices, and function as a model to guide the design of each Kasian location. The space conveys the essence of the Kasian brand—communication, teamwork, flexibility, and sustainability. Every wall is a work wall for brainstorming, and design studios can be reconfigured in 15 minutes for new working groups and client spaces. Kasian's planning principles of transparency, mobility, visibility, and innovation are showcased and serve as a benchmark for interior design excellence. Additionally, the office was designed to meet LEED®-CI (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design - Commercial Interiors) certification in Canada and certification was awarded in 2008.

textlist.text: Come and and experience the changing philosophy of workplace environments. Visitors will have the opportunity to tour this award-winning space, meet architects and interior designers, discover a unique design environment, and learn about recent Kasian projects. Designers and staff will be on hand to welcome and answer your questions.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Mount Dennis Garage opened on November 23, 2008. It is one of seven garages at the TTC. It consists of 250,000 square feet and services a fleet of approximately 245 buses. Facility features include 4 cleaning work stations, 16 repair hoists, 2 pits and 1 steam cleaning room.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Behind the scenes look at a bus maintenance and storage facility, meet one of the architects and ride a bus through the bus wash!

entrydata.text: Runnymede or Eglinton or Eglinton West

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Factory Theatre consists of two main buildings: the original 1869 house (known as John Mulvey House)and the 1910 addition, give Heritage Status by the Ontario Heritage Board in 1987. The original house was constructed in a classic Queen Anne Gothic design for the prominent Irish Toronto Merchant John Mulvey in 1869 and is attributed to Gundry & Langley. The house’s architectural features include an unusual asymmetrical façade with an irregular gabled roof, its fine buff brickwork with stone sills and wood mouldings and its Gothic arch entry. It was significant mansion in the Irish settled area that was know as Claretown. In 1909, the property was sold to the Roman Catholic Church, Parish of St. Mary and was used as their Arts and Literary Centre. The larger addition to the complex was built in 1910 and designed by J.M. Cowan. It includes a church hall set up in theatre style with an overhanging balcony that is still in use today. The addition’s main architectural feature is its distinctive façade that faces Adelaide Street and has a central oriel window and two flanking entrances with arched transoms.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The office is located in a circa-1916 brick and beam warehouse in Little Italy, on the south-east corner of College Street and Manning Avenue, west of Bathurst Street. Our philosophy is to work with human nature, rather than against it. Our workspace benefits from a panoramic view of the city which invites expansive thoughts, while raising awareness of our relationship to the larger world. Re-use of the warm, natural materials provides a sense of history. Movement through the space reveals breathe-able working areas that inspire big thinking, while accommodating various modes of participation. Model-making, at the core of our working method, is treated as interactive theatre happening at centre-stage location. An organic lighting arrangement evokes the bubbling up of bright ideas. In place of rigid partitions there are plug-in bar surfaces and informal seating areas that serve as soft edges. This approach re-imagines the board room as naturally permeable space. The office celebrates and supports what Farrow Partnership Architects does best - deliver reliable magic.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Come experience the daily workings of a midsize Toronto architectural firm. Get a hands-on opportunity to view working models, drawings and computer graphics. Slideshows of current projects and ideas will be running throughout the day. Our Architects and Interior Designers will also be on hand to welcome you and answer questions about our current projects.

textlist.text: Come for a sail in one of the largest man-made spaces in Toronto – the Outer Habour! Originally intended as a deep water shipping port, it’s now part nature reserve, and one of the largest freshwater harbours in the world. It features unique land & architecture re-purposing – with customized club houses made from old school portables, to wheel houses salvaged from Ontario Place’s sunken breakwater Lakers. The Outer Harbour serves as a cornerstone of the massive redevelopment project known as Lake Ontario Park.

For 2010, Westwood Sailing Club – an all volunteer non-profit organization, teaching adults sailing since 1967 without the expense of owning a boat – proudly plays its part as Port Lands ambassador, re-introducing Torontonians to their very own urban aquatic wilderness.
You won't believe you're 10 minutes from downtown Toronto!

For the brave, we offer quick sails into Toronto's amazing Outer Harbour on our sailing dinghies (See Photo, Conditions & Capacity Permitting - Adults Only! You may get wet!). Sailing is also one of best, environmentally friendly ways to view the incredible wild life along the Leslie Street Spit.
We'll take groups on tours of our unique clubhouse – introduce the basic concepts of sailing and bring people up close & personal with our small craft.
Few cities in the world offer such an inexpensive introduction to sailing for adults – especially in a protected freshwater harbour.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Canadian Lesbian and Gay Archives celebrated the grand opening of its new home on September 26, 2009. The CLGA is now housed in the historically designated Italianate style building, the Jared Sessions House, built 1859-60. The house was originally commissioned by Jared Sessions of Sessions, Carpenter and Company, wholesale sellers of boots and shoes. The house features characteristics of the style, particularly the hip roof with extended eaves and brackets. The CLGA was founded in 1973 as part of The Body Politic, Canada's gay liberation newsmagazine of record during the 1970s and 80s. It has grown from just a few boxes of material to become the second largest LGBT archive in the world. The CLGA is a world-class community based and supported collecting institution. 34 Isabella Street features a research reading room, a gallery and other spaces to display museum, art and archival collections as well as a large reference library.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Tours of the house will be conducted at regular intervals on Saturday and Sunday, providing a history of the Canadian Lesbian and Gay Archives and the Architectural History of the house. Information regarding the history of 34 Isabella Street and the recent renovation completed in 2009 will be on display. Exhibition of the National Portrait Collection, honouring individuals, who have made significant contributions to the growth of diverse, out and proud lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgendered communities in Canada, will also be on view. Volunteers will be on hand to answer questions.

textlist.text: Upon completion in 1931, this monumental 34-storey building represented a new generation of skyscrapers. It remained the tallest building in the Commonwealth until 1962. The immense banking hall, modeled after the Baths of Caracalla in Rome, projects an almost ecclesiastical sense of awe.

Commerce Court North is now part of a four acre property, comprised of four architecturally distinct office buildings linked by an outdoor central courtyard and vibrant underground retail mall. Commerce Court West, South and East were built in 1972 and designed by renowned modern architect, I.M. Pei.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Victorian school house in old Corktown. First school with a woman principal in Toronto, Mrs. Georgina Stanley Riches. Interesting architecture and history. National historic site of the Underground Railroad. The site of Thornton and Lucie Blackburn who escaped slavery in 1830 and built a house, barn and Toronto's first taxi cab service. Governor General award winning book 'I Got a Home in Glory Land' by Karolyn Smardz Frost based on this important national site. The seven classroom Victorian school is said to be possibly haunted. The school now houses Inglenook Community High School, one of the first alternative schools in Toronto. 'Narratives in the Making,' a book by Mary Beattie is a description of this unique, democratic, alternative school.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Take a look at an old working class Victorian school house in 1887. Interesting exterior and interior architecture. National Historic Site of Thornton and Lucie Blackburn on the school's grounds. Plaque and land art commemoration of the Underground Railroad and the Abolition Movement. See Inglenook Community High School, one of the first alternative schools in Toronto.

textlist.text: Taylor Smyth Architects has recently moved into a new office located in a 1950’s low rise office building on Davenport Road. Designed in pursuit of LEED Commercial Interior Silver certification, the open studio environment incorporates extensive green building strategies to increase the quality and occupant comfort of the space. High efficiency lighting equipped with daylight sensors provides a softly lit and energy efficient workplace. Through the selection of low VOC products, sustainably harvested wood, Green Guard certified furniture, and material resource reuse strategies, along with the attention to detail and sensitivity to materials typical of the firm’s aesthetic, the new studio serves as a symbol of Taylor Smyth Architects’ design philosophy.

The new office is a mixture of the raw and the refined – exposed structural steel I-beam columns, open web steel roof joists and tinted concrete floors are juxtaposed with a screen of staggered walnut slats interspersed with strips of clear acrylic. A custom designed boardroom table of solid bamboo sits on a blackened steel base. Photos of our finished projects are contrasted with images of projects under construction.

Visitors will have the opportunity to view our newly-renovated 3,700 square feet studio and experience what it is like to work in a mid-sized architectural office. Our work environment, like our projects, is inspired by certain fundamental criteria to which we believe all people respond: natural light, texture and colour, natural materials, a sense of openness and access to views of nature, balanced by a sense of sheltered enclosure.

At Taylor Smyth Architects we seek to create “poetry” in each project. And we find inspiration, drawn or interpreted, from both the unique vision and identity of our clients and the environments in which they live, work and play.

Visitors will be exposed to the different processes related to the practice: from pre-design to construction. They will be able to see models, sketches, drawings, computer renderings, sample materials and mock-ups from selected projects, and to personally interact with the architects to discuss a wide range of topics including design, construction and sustainability.

The renovation is slated to be LEED CI Silver certified, and the variety of measures that have been taken to achieve this will be documented throughout the office to graphically illustrate the variety of sustainable design possibilities.

textlist.text: Kadampa Meditation Centre Canada is the NKT-IKBU National Kadampa Temple in Canada. Built in 1904, it was a church belonging to the Christian Congregation until they sold the property in 2006 - after which time, it was extensively renovated to the current design. This design is based on traditional Buddhist Temple with the following features: vajras which represent bliss adorning the Temple roof; the traditional eight auspicious symbols that depict different aspects
of the spiritual path represented in gold exterior plaques

and two Deer and a Dharma Wheel over the main door. The deer symbolize the realizations of wisdom and compassion, and the Dharma Wheel symbolizes the continuation of Buddha's teachings in this world. These auspicious symbols are also repeated with smaller gold symbols on the interior shrine, and again etched in the glass of the mezzanine walls.

This Temple is dedicated to World Peace. It functions as an active Buddhist community with a Resident Teacher, a full set of Buddhist study programs, and prayers. The Temple also offers meditation classes and teachings to all who wish to develop inner peace. The Temple also functions as the meeting place for the great
Kadampa Meditation Centre Canada will have a the following activities on the go throughout the Doors Open weekend:

* Temple tours by teachers and senior students explaining the meaning of the symbolism and the Buddhas that will include the entire Temple: including the main meditation room, the secondary meditation room, the preparation room for prayers, and the social area.
* An art studio set up where attendees can watch gilding done on Buddha statues and an exhibition of how the Buddhas in the shrine area were prepared during construction.
* A video slide show of the building under construction.
* A video of the construction of the Kadampa Temple in France with an introduction to the Spiritual Director and Temple Development Director.
* A ten-minute breathing meditation led by a teacher on the hour and on the half hour in the main meditation room
* A Kids Area (colouring books provided) with a supervisor giving a kid -friendly Temple tour and with simple explanation of Buddhas
* A World Peace Cafe and a gift shop
* A guide book and an explanation of who we are will be given to all

Learn about the origins of the world’s oldest fraternity, its guiding principles, and its history.

Toronto Police Service will be attending with a community safety program, along with Toronto Fire and EMS vehicles. This Venue is KID FRIENDLY with activities for both parents and their children and a BBQ.

Rarely seen by the general public, the temple currently hosts several Masonic groups and their functions.

entrydata.text: Classic Wm. Tyrrell design, built for the Father of Confederation Sir Wm. P. Howland and his brothers, Lambton House served as a mid-point stagecoach and Royal Mail stop on the Dundas Highway. Originally it was an L shaped centre plan, two story red brick building with white coins, decorative diamond inserts and a course of sawtooth brick work - a Tyrell trademark feature easily viewed from the second floor of the trillaged wooden verandah that covers the front of the Hotel. The floor of the first level verandah extends on either side of the entrance steps, providing two small, convenient, roadside platforms at stirrup height for mounting a horse or bicycle. The drive shed roof line is visible on the east wall.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: There will be guided tours of the building. Local Historians will be available. There will also be displays about the historic Lambton House and the Village of Lambton Mills, as well as the Flora of the neighbouring Humber River - Canada's 26th Heritage River. There will be videos about Hurricane Hazel, the architectural features and restoration of the Lambton House and of the district. Visitors may purchase Tea, Coffee, Lemonade or Goodies.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Design - This church has been conceived as a reflection of the liturgical vision of its Baptist congregation. This vision has a dual focus - fellowship, which the church characterizes as horizontal relationships between people, and spirituality.The church serves both as a place of worship with a sanctuary for 1,600 and as a focal point of activity for the Chinese community in Scarborough, offering recreation (a large gymnasium) banquet facilities, and meeting places. Siting/Urban Design: The church is nestled into a clearing in a remnant wood lot, along Kennedy Road in suburban Scarborough. It is the focal point of a 200 seat chapel and a point of reference as one moves through the public circulation spaces of the church. Environmental Issues: The project included the City of Toronto’s first approved bio swale parking lot. Storm water is processed through a sequence of swales that are planted with specific plant materials and special soils. The project also achieved an extremely high level of energy efficiency at a very low cost, through a designed building envelope and heat recovery system.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The northern part of the Casa Loma Estate, comprising a Stables complex, Potting Shed and Hunting Lodge, was begun in 1905 by builder Herbert Elgie, according to the design of architect E. J. Lennox. Sir Henry Pellatt, one of Edwardian Canada's wealthiest men, was a prominent industrialist, financier and military officer of the Queen's Own Rifles. He lived in this 'country' property while his palatial house, Casa Loma, was constructed between 1911-1913. The Stables complex was the first building erected on the site and accommodated Pellatt's horses. An impressive structure, it features red brick and cast stone trim and its Mannerist-inspired design owes much to the stables of larger European houses. The Potting Shed, adjoining the Stables, features the remains of a once glazed semi-circular Conservatory. Today it is used by Casa Loma gardening staff for the propagation of household and bedding plants. The Hunting Lodge, Casa Loma (main house) and gardens are not participating in the Doors Open programme.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Enjoy exploring the northern part of the Casa Loma Estate which comprises a Stables complex and a working Potting Shed. It was begun in 1905 by builder Herbert Elgie, according to the design of architect E. J. Lennox for Sir Henry Pellatt, one of Edwardian Canada's wealthiest men. The Stables complex was the first building erected on the site and accommodated Pellatt's horses. An impressive structure, it features red brick and cast stone trim and its Mannerist-inspired design owes much to the stables of large European houses. Inside, there is a small exhibit on the Stables and Pellatt's horses. The Potting Shed, adjoining the Stables, features the remains of a once glazed semi-circular conservatory. Inside, there is a small photographic exhibit detailing the evolution of the estate gardens. The Hunting Lodge, Casa Loma (main building) and the Casa Loma gardens are not participating in the Doors Open programme.

textlist.text: Substantially completed in 1898, this church structure designed in a "modern gothic" style replaced an earlier frame one that stood on this location from 1856 to 1897. Its interior has frequently been described as "jewel-like", belieing its very plain if not austere exterior. It is exceptionally richly decorated with very fine woodwork, stunning stained glass windows, a dramatic high altar acting as the focal point of the sanctuary, and richly executed chancel stencilling. The organ, continually in use since its installation marks its centenary this year. Its interior essentially remains unchanged since 1932 when the interior appointments were completed.
First Evangelical Lutheran Church is used for services each and every Sunday. German language services are still held here more than 159 years after the congregation´s founding in 1851.
It is the "mother church" for many Lutheran congregations in Toronto who trace their roots to First Lutheran.

entrydata.text: 1313 Queen St. West was constructed in 1931 as City of Toronto Police Station Division 6 . It remained a police station until the early 1960's . It then became emergency housing with the city of Toronto for about 14 years . The building then became a Metro property until it was turned over to Artscape for a 20 year lease at $1 /year . This came about with the support of the community and many individuals with the vision that the building would become a community venue for organizations and also house 9 live /work artist studios managed by Artscape . Today the building is full of activity and artists are now living in the original stable house.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Learn the history of this former Police Station. Exhibition curated by Christopher Hume which displays works by Toronto artists inspired by local architecture. Historic tour (20 minutes) Saturday and Sunday at 1pm and 3pm.

textlist.text: The building is a modest building with a red brick facade, featuring minimal exterior ornamentation or grand architectural details. The chief exterior features are the windows and the main entrance. The circular windows on the north,west and south walls are divided into 18 segments, symbolizing the numerical value for the Hebrew word for life; "chai". The main entrance, located on the west side of the building, consists of a double sided staircase leading up to two large wooden doors.

This simple exterior masks a traditionally elegant and decorative Eastern European interior. The building is two stories high, so the sanctuary is separated into two distinct levels.The basement was once a small sanctuary, originally used for daily services and functions. It is now a modest school room, or "cheder", used for Sunday Hebrew school. The mikvah(ritual bath), although still on site, is no longer in use.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The public will have an opportunity to talk to present members who are descendants of the founders of the synagogue and ask any questions regarding the history of the synagogue and it's function. There will be handouts available with further details of the synagogue and it's history.

textlist.text: Built in 1905 as the Canadian Bank of Commerce building, it is classical in detail, noteworthy for its south facade, with its convex elevation and details of the stonework, including the engaged Ionic columns, cartouches, lettered fascia, cornice, and modulated parapet. The west facade is divided into bays with windows having articulated dressed stonework and elaborate cartouches. The details of the building demonstrate fine craftmanship.

The building is currently owned and operated as the world headquarters and couture fashion house of Stephan Caras Design. The interior is stylistically modern and designed by Stephan Caras himself. It features fine elements of fabric draping, fabric wall coverings, upholstery, and carefully crafted woodwork. Most notable is the elegant spiral staircase in the main room. The original oak stair case has been restored at the north end of the building along with the brickwork of the original north wall. Also notable is the original vault door (J & J Taylor Ltd.) that has been mounted and framed on the north wall. The building maintains its inherent history through these elements while blending the artistic expression of Stephan Caras.

We invite you to visit the world headquarters of Stephan Caras Design and get a glimpse into the fashion world of Stephan Caras. Located in the heart of downtown Toronto, you will experience an atmosphere equal to that of a European fashion house or chic New York boutique. Enter the main floor and view beautifully crafted lady's and men's garments made from exquisite European fabrics, designed by Stephan Caras, and made in house. Yes... made in Canada!
Tour the design studio, speak with Stephan Caras, and take the opportunity to see Stephan at work and get a better understanding of the creative process involved in designing his beautiful pieces.

textlist.text: Located on York University’s Keele Campus, the Archives of Ontario’s new state-of-the-art facility, designed by Bregman and Hamann to LEED Silver standards. The building is designed to offer enhanced services to the public and includes a large reading room, over 90 digital microfilm readers, audio and video booths, modern digitization and conservation labs and a classroom for educational programming. It features innovative climate controls and fire prevention technologies in its vaults to ensure the long-term preservation of the Archives’ collection. The building also features an exhibit area to display original archival materials.

The Archives of Ontario is the largest provincial archives in Canada, with a collection that includes 2.9 million photographs, more than 85,000 maps, 240,000 architectural drawings and over 40,000 hours of audio, video and film records. At the core of its collection are 100 kilometres of textual records. Stacked up, that’s taller than 180 CN Towers. These records date back to 1729, and reflect all aspects of public and private life in Ontario.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: From Log Cabin to LEED: Four Centuries of Ontario Architecture. The Archives of Ontario will be opening its doors for a behind-the-scenes look at its new state-of-the-art facility and will be displaying original records from its holdings showing the development of architecture in Toronto from the Eighteenth Century to the Twenty-First. Architectural drawings of many of the buildings featured in Doors Open will be on display in our reading room. May, 2010 also marks the opening of Architectural Dialogues, the Archives exhibit on the work of renowned Toronto architects Moriyama and Teshima. Nearly 100 original records will be on display demonstrating the progress of a major building from proposal to construction. Toronto buildings featured in the exhibit include Toronto Reference Library, Japanese Canadian Cultural Centre (now Noor Cultural Centre), Scarborough Civic Centre, North York Civic Centre, Bata Shoe Museum and Vari Hall. If you’ve ever been interested in researching your family history, your hometown or one of the millions of stories from your province’s past, now is your chance to find out how. Archives staff will be on-site to offer tours of the building.

textlist.text: Built in 1938 and dedicated in 1939 by Heber J. Grant President of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the Ossington Chapel was the first built by the church in Central and Eastern Canada. It was home to the Toronto Branch. The building is on the church's register of historical buildings. It has been in continuous use since the first meeting in October 1938 with 213 people in attendance. The exterior is a golden brown brick with a brass name plate over the front entrance and the corner stone clearly visable. Contents of the corner stone remain sealed and are documented by church leaders and records from the time. The interior has a beautiful walnut accent. The original building had a chapel for worship services, Relief Society Room for women, five classrooms, a recreation hall and a kitchen. There have been two additions. The building is mostly original including a beautiful hand carved pulpit.

The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormon)was introduced in Ontario in 1836 and has had a continuous presence since. Today, there are seven meeting houses in Toronto and over 45,000 members. This year marks the Toronto Stake's 50th anniversary.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: At the beautiful Ossington Chapel of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (sometimes known as Mormons) visitors will be treated to an uplifting museum-quality art exhibit "Reflections of Christ" from the artwork of world renowned photographer Mark Mabry. This work is a pictoral history of the life of Jesus Christ. As visitors tour the building they will see unique features such as the original pulpit from which many key leaders and three presidents of the Church spoke, the beautiful period women's meeting room with vaulted ceiling and original fireplace, the primary childrens meeting room, cultural or recreation hall, chapel and leaded glass windows throughout the building. The kitchen will display easily obtainable 72 hour emergency kits and home preparedness items. Video presentations will depict the history of the Church in Upper Canada during the 1830's and the Church today. Demonstrations throughout the building including family history, youth programs, young single adult and our emphasis on the family will add to the interaction of guests and members.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: John St Roundhouse - Toronto Railway Heritage Centre

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The John Street Roundhouse is an architectural wonder. It is the home of the Toronto Railway Historical Association (TRHA), which is bringing Toronto’s railway heritage back to life.

textlist.text: * Several restored historic structures including the Don Station - the only surviving remnant of the Grand Trunk Railway in Toronto;
* an operational miniature steam railway with rides for visitors;
* the original 120-foot long locomotive turntable, which has been fully restored and is operational;
* 10 historic engines, freight and passenger cars;
* An indoor model railway show featuring layouts from across the province.

textlist.text: Take a walking tour of the newest part of Regent Park. Phase one of the Regent Park revitalization includes all new buildings:
* 246 Sackville Street, the first new family building for Regent Park tenants
* 252 Sackville Street, a new seniors building for Regent Park tenants
* One Cole Street, the first condominium building built as part of the revitalization
* One Oak, another new family rental building for Regent Park tenants, now under construction
* One Park West, the second condominium building now under construction
* new townhomes - both rental and condominium, now under construction
* Cole Street - a new street, and Regent and Sackville Streets, which have been re-opened after more than half a century

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: On your tour of phase one of the Regent Park revitalization, staff will show you around the new parts of neighbourhood and tell you about the revitalization project. This area, bounded by Dundas, Parliament, Oak and Sackville Streets, has new buildings and townhomes - both rental and condominiums - and streets that are open for the first time in half a century. Start your tour in the lobby of the first new rental building, 246 Sackville, and end at the presentation centre, where you can see a community scale model showing the entire revitalization.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Humber Arboretum Centre for Urban Ecology

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Humber Arboretum Centre for Urban Ecology is an award-winning LEED® (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) Gold-certified facility showcasing the latest in green design and technology. One of the first LEED Gold buildings in Toronto, the Centre is a venue for education, community programming and research into urban ecology and sustainable development. Sustainable features of the building include: passive solar heat sources, high performance windows and super-insulation, a vegetated ('green') roof for storm water management and passive cooling, a biofilter system for sewage and grey water treatment, water conserving toilets, a cistern to collect roof top runoff and supply landscape irrigation, natural cooling and ventilating, natural day lighting, high efficiency luminaries, occupancy sensor controls, a high efficiency gas boiler, environmentally friendly, and locally sourced building materials, low VOC finishes/ sealants, and an integrated monitoring and control system to achieve energy efficiency and occupant comfort and to provide data relating to the effectiveness of green technologies in an urban public building.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The visitor will experience the beauty of our urban natural areas and stunning garden oasis through the lens of sustainable modern architectural design. While visitors are always welcome at the Centre for Urban Ecology, this weekend we will celebrate and highlight the stunning architecture and progressive sustainable design features of the building and its integrated landscape ecosystems. Please join us on Saturday at 11am and 1pm for architect's tours provided by Taylor Hazell Architects, on Sunday for Director's tours at 11am and 1pm, or stop in anytime between 10am and 2pm for a casual stroll through the building and its secret gardens overlooking the Humber River valley woods and meadows.

across Canada, internationally and offers a variety of programs and services.

textlist.text: Although not built as a church, this heritage structure has been occupied by religious groups for over 100 years. First built as a Foresters Hall in the 1880’s, it became in succession home to Christian Scientists, a Church of Christ congregation and a Mennonite group. In 1943 the building was acquired by the First Narayever Congregation, named after the hometown of its founding members, Naraiev, located in what is now Ukraine.

Due to its size and age, the simple design of the Narayever differs dramatically from the newer synagogues erected in Toronto in subsequent years. As populations shifted, the fortunes of the building ebbed and by the 1970s the building had fallen into a state of semi-disrepair. But in the 1980’s it underwent a revival by younger worshippers, and eventually became the vibrant, gender-equal, socially conscious community of today.

The original red brick building has undergone minor renovations but essentially remains a modest but warm and inviting structure. On display will be artifacts rescued from the Holocaust, modern textile art executed by local crafts people, as well as the original Yiddish signage marking its early humble beginnings.

Guided tours. Short talks will describe how the building was renovated and enlarged to adjust to the changing nature of the membership, and tell about the second Narayever congregation. Guests will learn the interesting symbolism of various religious items, including a historical Torah ark curtain rescued from the Holocaust as well as newer textiles and ritual items executed by local artists. There will be a display of the sacred hand-written Torah scrolls and an explanation of how they are printed and constructed.

Visitors will learn how this modest building evolved into a thriving contemporary downtown institution that now serves a broad spectrum of membership and reaches out to the larger community through organizations like Out of the Cold, Habitat for Humanity, Jewish Family and Child Service, Kensington Gardens nursing home and Everdale Organic Farm and Environmental Learning Centre, with which the synagogue hosts an organic greenmarket on its front lawn during the warmer months.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Zion Primitive Methodist Church was built in 1873 by the Methodists of L'Amaroux, the Finch community between Victoria Park and Warden, on land donated by early settler Henry Scrace. The Church and adjacent cemetery was acquired by the borough of North York in 1971, and in 1977 "designated" under the Ontario Heritage Act as an example of a typical rural church.

textlist.text: - Tours of Zion Church Cultural Centre
- Children's activities inside and outside (weather permitted)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Horse Palace is an art deco structure that was originally constructed in 1932 to house horses during the Canadian National Exhibition and the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair. In addition to providing world renowned stabling, the Horse Palace is also home to a year-round riding academy. The Academy's portion of the Horse Palace has been substantially remodelled, providing a warm and pleasant atmosphere for the school's clients, miniature farm animals and horses.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The Riding Academy at the Horse Palace invites you to come and meet our school horses and miniature farm animals! There will also be tours of our facilities and riding demonstrations. Equestrian Demonstration at the top of each hour.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Soldiers' Tower was built between 1919-1924 in memory of the 627 men and one woman lost to the University during the Great War, 1914-1918. Carved on the Memorial Screen are the names of those who lost their lives in that struggle. The clock and carillon were added in 1927. After the Second World War, the names of the 557 men and women lost in that conflict were carved on the two walls of the Memorial Archway. Today the Soldiers’ Tower may inspire us to remember and appreciate our democratic freedoms.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The Memorial Room, one of Canada's smaller military museums, will be open to visitors. Members of the Soldiers' Tower Committee (a volunteer committee of alumni and friends of the University, many of whom are war veterans) will be present to explain the artifacts. The Carillon will not be open for Doors Open.
Henry Sproatt and Ernest R. Rolph, 1924

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The building at 501 Adelaide Street East is one of Toronto Community Housing's newest buildings. Built as part of the revitalization of Regent Park, it is home to a mix of tenants, including some households who used to live in phase one of Regent Park. It has 180 units, some with two floors with as many as 5 bedrooms. The building includes state of the art environmental technologies including heat recovery ventilation units, high efficiency boilers and a green roof. Amenities for tenants include a landscaped inner courtyard with a splash pad and children's play area and an amenity room with extra high ceilings looking out into the courtyard.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Your Doors Open visit to 501 Adelaide Street East will allow you to visit the main floor of this private residence. This includes an amenity room with extra high ceilings where there will be staff available to answer questions about the building and the Regent Park revitalization. This space opens up onto a landscaped inner courtyard with a splash pad and children's play area. Also on the main floor is Toronto Community Housing's accessibility assessment centre where tenants from across the city come to be assessed for modifications in their unit to accommodate accessibility requirements. The assessment centre includes a model kitchen and bathroom. Adam Feldmann, the Associate at Architects Alliance responsible for this building, will be available to talk guests about the design or the building.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: This rare Regency Picturesque cottage is a graceful monument to John and Jemima Howard, the couple who founded High Park. John Howard, one of Toronto's first architects, as well as City Engineer and Surveyor, built Colborne Lodge in 1837. The site is restored to reflect life in the mid-Victorian period of the 1870s.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Guided tours every twenty minutes starting at noon and last tour at 3:40 pm. Tours run approximately up to 45 minutes and there will be a scavenger activity for children to do while on tour.

entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Church of the International Society of Krishna Consciousness, the former Avenue Road Church, is designated on architectural and contextual grounds. Built in 1899 as the Presbyterian Church of the Convenant, it is characteristic of the work of Toronto architects Gordon and Helliwell. The bold use of white Kingston limestone makes it a significant landmark in context with both the Church of the Messiah (also designed by Gordon and Helliwell) and the adjacent house on the opposite side of Avenue Road. Used by the Presbyterians until 1925 and then by various groups, it was taken over by the Church of Nazarene with Charles Templeton as preacher in 1941. The building was gutted by fire in 1944 but was subsequently restored to use. It was purchased and converted into the Hare Krishna temple in 1975-76.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Guided tours of the building highlighting the architectural, historical and spiritual history of the building. Visual displays of media news clippings, municipal documentation and interesting publications related to the building. Kids activities, free snacks and refreshments for the public! Regular Sunday programming open to the public 5:30-8:30pm, including a Free Vegetarian feast served at 7:30pm

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: The Drake opened in 1890 as D. A. Small’s Hotel. At the time, the area was a major Canadian Pacific Railway hub that linked Downtown with the lakeside summer homes of Toronto’s western beaches. For the next half century, the Hotel transitioned through several owners and names including Hotel Cecil and the Stardust. In 1949, Michael Lundy purchased the property, renamed it the Drake, expanded the building and created many of the improvements visible today, including the grand staircase in the lobby and the addition of a Lounge and restaurant.

The current owner purchased the property in late 2001 and undertook the extensive renovations that gave the hotel its current form. The Drake re-opened its doors in February of 2004 and has since gone on to proudly redefine the Toronto boutique hotel experience.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The design process engages the history of the Drake and its neighbourhood, and provides those who walk through its doors a unique, storied experience that pays homage to exceptional and timeless design. Guests can enjoy tours of the public spaces and hotel rooms, as well as works from the Drake's ongoing art exhibitions.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The entire south facade of the worship space,glazed with clear glass to passively harness the winter sun's energy extends the sacred space of the worship area into the garden. The "green roof" garden over the underground parking, with its drought-tolerant plants and drip-irrigation system, reduces potable water use by 78%. Waterless urinals, dual flush toilets, and solar-powered low-flow faucets provide an additional 47% water reduction. Maximizing insulation values;highly efficient mechanical systems that incorporate heat recovery methodologies;the use of passive solar heating; maximizing natural ventilation and daylighting;use of room occupancy and daylight sensors to control electrical lighting;incorporating a "living wall" of tropical plants to purify and condition the air are all strategies that have been used to achieve 50% energy use reduction to further reduce the carbon footprint. Incorporation of 15% recycled materials, 10% salvaged content, 30% regionally produced content, and the diversion of 59% of construction waste are all worthy acheivements. Tours,a kiosk and a website all help to explain the various sustainable design features that contribute to a greener Toronto

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Tours will run continuously from 11:30am to 4pm on Saturday and from 2pm to 5pm on Sunday. The Architect, Roberto Chiotti will give a presentation on Saturday at 12 noon. Dennis O'Hara, a professor at the Elliott Allen Institute of Theology and Ecology will give a presentation on Sunday at 2pm. **Opening time on Saturday has been changed from 10am to 11:30am due to a funeral service.
Roberto Chiotti from Larkin Architects Ltd., 2006

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: St. George's Greek Orthodox Church is a Heritage-designated landmark for the City of Toronto. Built in 1897 by the Canadian architect John Wilson Siddall, the building functioned as a synagogue until 1937 when it was acquired by the parish of Saint George. The present state of the building reflects alterations undertaken during the period 1981-1987. With the exception of its Romanesque façade and few Moorish capitals, the renovated edifice is now more thoroughly Byzantine in its layout and aesthetic decor. The church interior is unique in being the only one outside of Greece to have been painted in its entirety by the Pachomaioi monks, Theophilos and Chrysostomos, master iconographers from Mount Athos, Greece.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: There will be a 20 minute guided tour running every half hour, going through the architecture and iconography of the church. There will be a Byzantine icon exhibit at the basement of the church. Ladies Auxiliary will be having a bake sale with Greek pastries.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The OAA building opened in 1992 and was designed by Toronto architect Ruth Cawker, winner of a 1989 province-wide design competition. The contemporary two-storey building is lifted from its hilltop site on columns and features bright interiors lit with natural light. Main floor uses include a double height exhibition gallery and lounge, a conference centre that can be adapted to various configurations, meeting rooms, the boardroom and several offices. The upper floor offices are located around the exterior of the building with an atrium that provides views to the main floor below.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: A self-guided tour of the building. During the tour visitors will be able to view an exhibit of the 2010 OAA award winners. Volunteers will be on hand to answer any questions. Information about the building and the Association will be available.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Little Trinity Anglican Church was built in seven months, and opened in February 1844. It was the second Anglican church in Toronto. (St. James was the first.) It is now the oldest church building surviving in Toronto. Founded by Bishop John Strachan, Enoch Turner and William Gooderham, it was established to serve the poor (Irish) working class of the east end of Toronto. Though simple in style inside, it is a fine example of early Gothic Revival church architecture. The bell in the bell tower dates from 1844, and is still rung before services to call people in the neighbourhood to worship. The baptistry is original and the pews date from the 1870s. Because the city population was growing, the church was enlarged in 1889. A fire in 1961 led to some reconstruction and renovation which returned the church to its original design.

textlist.text: You can expect to speak with knowledgeable storytellers. Look at photos, slide shows and scrapbooks. View the wall memorials. Examine displays of memorabilia from our archives. Discover key features of gothic architecture. Perhaps you'll want to ring the church bell. Examine the exterior of historic church rectory next door - 1852, by Frederick Cumberland. Learn about Reverend Sanson, minister for 50 years, and Reverend Dixon, after whom the local community centre, Dixon Hall, is named.
Learn about the active ministries of the current congregation of 400.
We are easy walking distance to the Distillery District.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The King Edward Hotel was built by the George Gooderham Toronto Hotel Company to meet the demand in the rising metropolis for a grand hotel. When it opened in 1903, the hotel was affectionately known as the “King Eddy” and embraced by the entire city. The eight-storey building, designed by eminent Chicago architect Henry Ives Cobb and prominent Toronto architect E.J. Lennox, provided luxury and service in dramatic settings. The 18-storey tower, with its spectacular rooftop Crystal Ballroom, was added in 1920-21 to enlarge the hotel. Although threatened with demolition in the 1970s, the hotel was revitalized in 1980-81. On its 107th anniversary in 2010, Le Méridien King Edward, Toronto’s first luxury hotel and one of the first large-scale hotels in Ontario, remains a vibrant and elegant meeting place for local and international visitors. An important symbol of commerce, the King Edward Hotel is a provincially significant commercial building. The hotel is also closely associated with Toronto’s rise as an international centre of business and entertainment, and remains a vibrant part of Ontario’s cultural fabric.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Discover Toronto’s first luxury hotel The King Edward during the 11th Annual Door Open Toronto. Tours offered Saturday May 29th and Sunday, May 30th from 10:00am to 5:00pm, last admittance is 4:00pm. Explore the rich history and pedigree of the venerable hotel. The famous rooftop Crystal Ballroom will be included in the tour along with the Sovereign Ballroom and many other intriguing areas of the hotel. Le Méridien King Edward also offers an alluring overnight package. Enjoy the full historical experience plus a spectacular dinner from the Edwardian times as well as behind closed doors discoveries including the Beatles suite. These ‘insider’ privileges are only accessible with the overnight room and dinner package. Le Méridien King Edward hotel is a grand landmark that the city of Toronto has grown up around and is ready to open its doors to guests of Toronto and abroad for a truly historical experience to remember! Tafelmusik performances Sat. 10:30, 11:30, 1:30, 2:30 and Sun. 10:30 & 11:30.

entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Gardiner Museum, dedicated to ceramic art, was originally designed by Keith Wagland in 1984. With its 3rd floor expansion in 2006, designed by Kuwabara Payne McKenna Blumberg Architects, the museum enjoys an expansion and extension of its original footprint while presenting a bolder image to the street still in keeping with the intimate scale for which the original building was admired. The former pink granite exterior was replaced with polished buff limestone, fully respecting its situation between the neo-classical Lillian Massey and Queen-Anne style buildings of Victoria University. The strategic addition of 1400 square feet allows the museum to host international exhibitions of contemporary works while showcasing its expanding permanent collection. Education and studio spaces were created along with enlarged and improved collections storage.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The public will be welcomed to all the public areas of the museum and will have an opportunity to try their hand at clay activities while working with the Gardiner's professional ceramic artists.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: Gzowski House is now the national headquarters of Frontier College, Canada's original national literacy organization. Robert Alexander Laidlaw had the house built in 1913 after his marriage to Julia G. Gayley.

The elegant two-and-a-half storey building is an excellent example of Tudor Gothic-Revival architecture, and is listed in The City of Toronto’s Inventory of Heritage Properties. The design features fine brickwork and stone trim with casement windows and stone lintels throughout. The two-storey bay on the west side, with the triple row of windows, contains a one-turn staircase which leads to the second floor.

Some original interior details of the house are intact. The wide outer front door opens to a small vestibule. The inner twelve-section wooden door leads to a large entrance hail. Beyond that is a room with a beautiful fireplace of green marble surrounded by decorative woodwork. To its left is the library, with a fine carved stone fireplace and an ornate decorative ceiling. All three rooms are panelled in wood, in the same rectangular-pattern as the inner front door.

Guided tours of Canada's original literacy organization. Founded in 1899 by a group of university students, Frontier College began by sending volunteers to the frontiers of Canada: logging camps, mining towns, and rail gangs. They worked alongside the workers by day and taught by night.

Today, we work in communities across Canada by training volunteers to help children, youth and adults with low literacy improve their skills. Each year, more than 2,000 volunteers work with over 16,000 participants in inner-city classrooms, shelters, prisons, community centres and Aboriginal communities to help them achieve their goals and participate more fully in their communities.
Visitors will have the opportunity to experience a museum-quality display celebrating 110 years of the organization. This display was launched in 2009 at Pier 21 in Halifax.
Children will have a chance to visit a Frontier College Reading Tent, fully stocked with books and volunteers ready to share a story (weather permitting).
All visitors will have a chance to meet and chat with learners, volunteers and staff who are involved in literacy programs.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Built in 1957, 51 Mercer Street is a modern factory building that has served many functions including an elastics factory, television studio, and is now a comedy theatre. The building is currently owned by the Bitove Group (along with the neighbouring 99 Blue Jays Way, which now houses Gretzky’s Restaurant, with the original bricks and mortal dating back to 1856.) The theatre has been built with aluminum, steel, concrete, brick and gyprock.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The Second City Toronto is a landmark cultural attraction with a celebrated history of launching the careers of Canada’s finest comedic actors. Through artifacts, photos, video and candid stories told by our alumni, we’ll tell the story of our 35-year comedic legacy in Toronto. This interactive museum includes tours facilitated by our actors, mini-performances and improvisation workshops for kids and adults.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Toronto Botanical Garden offers an array of 12 award-winning themed gardens spanning nearly four acres, designed to educate and inspire. You'll also find a complete range of innovative indoor and outdoor learning experiences for all ages including programs, garden tours, nature day camps, field trips and an extensive horticultural library; LEED Silver Certified Building with an energy-efficient sloping green roof and award-winning ecologically conscious design; rental facilities; garden shop and seasonal café.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Take part in guided tours of the LEED silver certified building and award-winning themed gardens led by TBG tour guides. Visit the TBG Café for freshly prepared jams, drinks and other treats using locally-grown harvested produce as part the Edible Summer Exhibition. Families are invited to explore the art and science of plants in The James Boyd Children's Centre.

entrydata.text: Artscape Wychwood Barns - The Stop Community Food Centre

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Green Barn, a new satellite site of The Stop Community Food Centre, is a 10,000 square foot sustainable food production and education centre that engages people to grow, eat, learn about, celebrate and advocate for healthy, local food. Located in the Artscape Wychwood Barns, the dynamic redevelopment of the historic Wychwood streetcar barns at Christie and St. Clair, The Green Barn includes a year-round greenhouse, sheltered garden, bake oven, compost demonstration project, community kitchen and classroom.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The Green Barn's greenhouse and classroom space will be open for tours. Find out about our year-round organic food production program and how we support our community with fresh, local produce. The Stop's Green Barn Market, featuring Ontario fruits, vegetables, meats, cheese and prepared foods, will run outdoors on the west side of the Barns from 8:00 a.m. - 1 p.m.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Book the Beach! This walking tour of the Beach coordinated by the Beach BIA will begin at the Beaches Branch of the Toronto Public Library. Originally designed by Eden Smith and opened in 1916, the library which was funded through a Carnegie grant, was remodelled in 1980 and then again in 2005. A well-loved bronze sculpture of Wordsworth the owl with its baby owls, by noted sculptor Ludzer Vandermolen, sits proudly out front. The tour will be "book-ended" by the R.C. Harris Water Filtration Plant (no inside access), the art-deco gem situated at the far end of Queen Street East, just past the Neville Park loop. This "palace of purification" is also notable for having been featured in Michael Ondaatje's In the Skin of a Lion.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: The Beach is a unique lakeside neighbourhood that hasn’t forgotten its roots or its connections to the water. The tour given by noted historian, Gene Domagala, will begin at 10 am and noon at the Beaches Library, 2161 Queen St. E., just west of Lee Ave., wind past historic properties, then head south on Glen Manor to the Boardwalk. Walkers will continue as far east as the Balmy Beach Club and then head back to the site of the old Scarboro’ Beach Amusement Park, Leuty Lifesaving Station and Kew Williams Cottage in Kew Gardens. Following the tour, visitors will have an opportunity to enjoy charming stores and restaurants in the Beach. Saturday 2pm at the Beaches Branch Library, see examples of Toronto’s delightful Art Deco buildings in a visual presentation by Tim Morawetz, author of Art Deco Architecture in Toronto: A Guide to the City’s Buildings from the Roaring Twenties and the Depression. This popular style of architecture, prevalent between 1925 and the 1940s,influenced the design of office buildings, stores, civic buildings, apartments and cinemas across the city.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The building is an older former industrial building on the site of the Heintzman Piano Factory lot. The building was purchased and renovated by the Riwoche Society of Canada. It now stands as a Tibetan Buddhist Temple with a magnificent meditation hall representative of this vibrant culture.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Highlights of your visit will include a guided tour on the special features of a Tibetan Buddhist shrine. An introduction and demonstration of the melodious sound of the ritual musical instruments.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Officially opened on April 7, 1930, the Canada Permanent Building is located in the heart of Toronto's financial district. It was constructed at the beginning of the Depression and the use of materials and sense of craftsmanship is very apparent. F. Hilton Wilkes' design for the skyscraper was influenced by classical architecture. Of particular note in the Corinthian columns are the Canadian symbols of wheat sheaves and fleurs-de-lys. The grand Romanesque entrance is magnificent with its coffered vault flanked by fluted pilasters. The Banking Hall was restored to its former grandeur by CIBC Mellon between May and December 2001. Recent additions include the chandeliers, designed as replicas of the originals. Their circular design is Art Deco, another example of the Art Deco style of the building.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Self-guided tours of award-winning restoration of the Art Deco Banking Hall in 2001.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Converted into a theatre in 1971-1972 by the University Alumnae Dramatic Club, many parts of the building still allude to its former use as Toronto's #4 Fire Station. The original roof structure and the arched east window remain virtually untouched.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Self guided tour; archives and costume display.

textlist.text: The Artscape Wychwood Barns are the conversion of a former TTC streetcar maintenance complex into space for artists' live-work studios, work-only studios, community gallery, office space for environmental and cultural organizations, and space for community events.
The converted building has applied for LEED gold certification, and is surrounded by a new City of Toronto park.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: There will be tours of the building and site at 10, 12, 2 and 4 p.m., conducted by Bruce Rosensweet, Director of Properties for Artscape. There is an artists' market planned for the Covered Street, and a show by craftspersons in the Community Gallery. Some of the live-work studios will be open.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: In 1890, the Officers of the Toronto Garrison founded the Royal Canadian Military Institute with the then Governor General of Canada, The Earl Grey, as its patron. Earl Grey laid the cornerstone of the existing premises in 1907. Today, the heritage building is well known to the public as a "city landmark" - an Edwardian edifice flanked distinctively by two 19th-century cannons. Substantial interior space is devoted to museum galleries displaying exhibits drawn from the Institute's extensive collections. The 30,000 -volume research Library's holdings include significant collections of primary documents relating to Canada's military history. There is also a curatorial workshop and a small research area for visiting scholars. The Institute has flourished as a pre-eminenet library and military museum and serves as an informal forum for discussions related to matters of "security and defence." For over a century the RCMI's members have formed a special community of men and women interested in military arts, science and literature, as well as the independence and success of Canada.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Access to a facility that is normally private. Guided tours by RCMI Members. View Canadian History and artefacts and in particular Canadian Military History.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: From concrete to living garden, the Toronto City Hall podium roof, where visiting dignitaries were once welcomed at the “front door” of the Council Chamber, will be reopened as the city’s largest, publicly accessible green roof garden at this year’s Doors Open Toronto.

Approximately 3,250 m2 (35,000 square feet) of concrete on the podium roof has been transformed into living vegetation to reduce the building’s environmental impact and for the year round enjoyment of Torontonians and visitors to the city.
New landscaped gardens, a courtyard framing the Council Chamber, a podium terrace, and new walkways provide unique views from this urban oasis in the heart of the city.
A diversity of plant species, grown regionally, has been selected for the City Hall podium roof for their seasonal colour and ability to withstand difficult rooftop conditions.

Kick off your experience on the City Hall podium green roof by joining Mayor David Miller on Saturday May 29 at 11:00 a.m. for the official opening ceremony, including meeting the project architect team and enjoying entertainment for the whole family.

Stroll through the gardens either on your own using the self-guided tour, or accompany one of the architects as they explain the design vision that includes a diversity of plant species and a kaleidoscope of changing colour throughout the year.

Visit the landscaped gardens via the new walkways or sit quietly on one of the many benches which allow you to view the garden’s unique linear design. Tour the open courtyard framing the Council Chamber, and the podium terrace that offers a unique view of the city overlooking Nathan Phillips Square.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Lorraine Kimsa Theatre for Young People

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The home of Lorraine Kimsa Theatre for Young People, formerly Young Peoples Theatre (YPT), is an Ontario Heritage building; it has played many roles since it's original construction in 1887. Some of its starring roles include a stable for the horses that pulled the Toronto Street Railway Company's Streetcars; an electric generating plant for the company between 1891 to 1906; and a warehousefor the TTC. In 1977, YPT transformed the building into a children's theatre. The Toronto Historical Board awarded YPT the award of Merit for its imaginative and sympathetic treatment of an important landmark that might otherwise have been destroyed.

textlist.text: We will offer behind the scenes tours highlighting some of the architectural challenges and oddities of Lorraine Kimsa Theatre for Young People.
Plus don't miss our hands on kids activity where budding architects get a chance to have a go at building a mock stage for one of next season's fantastic shows.
