entrydata.text: 75 Sherbourne St (Front St) 504 Streetcar to Sherbourne

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: 19th century vernacular Architecture by early Toronto area builders 1816-1860

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Black Creek Pioneer Village celebrates its 50th Anniversary in 2010. Step back in time and experience the life and times of a 19th century rural village. Black Creek Pioneer Village is an example of a typical crossroads community found in the Toronto area during the 1800's. These buildings, constructed of log, post and beam, frame, board and batten, and brick are superb examples of local 19th century vernacular architecture. See demonstrations by interpreters in period dress, visit the farm animals, and discover heritage gardens. Join in fun hands-on archaelogy demonstations on Saturday May 29th with the Toronto Chaper of the Ontario Archaeological Society that includes a variety of displays and activities related to First Nations and EuroCanadian settlement of the GTA.

textlist.text: Shamrock Bowl is one of the most unique event venues to hold corproate team building or social events. Recently renovated, it is the oldest and largest 5-pin bowling alley that still remains in Toronto, the city in which this popular team-building activity was invented back in 1909.
Guests will experience 5-pin bowling in this retro 12-lane bowling alley while enjoying its elegant ambiance and memorabilia.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Enjoy a retro-glam 5-pin bowling experience at this recently renovated historic bowling alley.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Portlands Energy Centre is a brand new, $730 million, state-of-the art generating station located in the eastern industrial section of the Port lands of Toronto. It provides up to 550 megawatts of power, enough to serve approximately 500,000 homes in central Toronto. It is fueled by natural gas which is one of the most efficient and cleanest fuels for generating electricity. Portlands Energy Centre operates about 40 percent of the time, primarily during peak hours on regular business days.

textlist.text: Portlands Energy Centre is a combined cycle power plant, where natural gas is burned to produce electricity in two ways (or cycles). In Cycle 1, natural gas is piped into the plant and combusted to turn a gas turbine, producing the first cycle of energy. In Cycle 2, the heat created by burning gas is captured to produce steam which turns a steam turbine, producing the second cycle of energy. Adding the second cycle increases the amount of electricity produced by the natural gas. This translates into lower fuel usage and lower emissions for every kilowatt of electricity produced.

The powerhouse building is 37 metres tall and covers 12,561 square metres. It will be open to the general public for the first time during this Doors Open Toronto. Come and see where the electricity is produced that keeps your lights, air conditioners and computers running. 45 minute orientation/hard hat guided tour every hour on the hour. Protiective wear must be worn and is provided. Ages 12 and up.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Ellis Building is a classic example of early 20th-century industrial loft design, featuring exposed red brick, large windows & mushroom cap columns. Originally home of stationary firm Barber-Ellis Company, Diamond & Schmitt Architects acquired and renovated the property in 2004. The interior has a circular flow that allows for intimate team groupings & ease of interaction among staff and clients in a bright, naturally lit space. Established in Toronto in 1975, Diamond and Schmitt Architects practices worldwide. Award-winning work includes the greenest campus in North America for the University of Ontario Institute of Technology, in Oshawa; the Bahen Center for Information Technology at the University of Toronto & the expansion of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra Hall. The Israeli Foreign Ministry, the Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts, Washington D.C.’s Shakespeare Theatre and Southbrook Vineyards are cited among the world's ten best buildings for the years when they were completed. A leader in sustainable design, the firm is committed to reducing the ecological impact of architecture through innovation & has more than 30 projects on track for LEED certification.

textlist.text: Ask an architect. View models and images of works in progress. Explore the workings and features of this busy architecture practice. We will offer presentations and discussion every half hour of current projects, including the New Mariinsky Opera House in St. Petersburg, Russia; Evergreen Brick Works; the Montreal Symphony hall, Corus Quay, the new Sick Kids research tower and academic, recreation and healthcare facilities across Canada.
3:15PM A green roof with a college underneath: Algonquin College in Ottawa goes LEED Platinum
4:15PM Building in the Desert: Santa Fe Community College and New Mexico Highlands University
1:15PM Bridgepoint Hospital and the Don Jail

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Formally opened on January 22, 1992, the City of Toronto Archives was designed by Zeidler Roberts Partnership to be a safe, secure and efficient archives, as well as an inviting research facility and a complement to its historic surroundings. Architectural highlights include: an ultra-modern, climate controlled storage area to accommodate 123,000 boxes; a skylit central atrium and exhibition area; pink terrazzo staircase; 60-seat theatre; and a two-storey, skylit Research Hall where researchers can access City records, photographs and maps.

textlist.text: As part of Doors Open, Toronto’s archival community invites you to participate in "Step Into Your Archives” on Saturday May 29th. Take part in a full day of activities that explore the link between yesterday and tomorrow. Stroll through displays from some of the outstanding archives operating in Ontario. See our new exhibit 'A New Lease on Life: Rental Housing in 20th century Toronto' and pick up a research guide that will help you research your house. Don't miss our theatre where you can view archival films that explore the themes of our new exhibit on the history of rental housing in Toronto. Be sure to go behind the scenes and visit the conservation and digitization labs normally closed to the public. See our experts at work and learn how historical materials are maintained and preserved for future generations.
“Step Into Your Archives” is presented in conjunction with the Toronto Area Archivists Group (TAAG). Please note that the Archives will be participating in Doors Open on Saturday May 29th only.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Located on the fourth floor of an old industrial building on College Street in Little Italy. The interior was designed to promote team work and creative thinking by providing a healthy and bright environment. A large open studio space is encircled with large windows around the perimeter. L-shaped workstations are aligned in the centre of the studio and are customized to specifically meet the ergonomic requirements for each individual employee.

textlist.text: 2:30pm talk by Tania Bortolotto on why design excellence is vital, why it does not exist more than it should and how to make it happen. Tania will be speaking on how design excellence is a vehicle to maximizing our health and well being and how it has a profound impact on our levels of happiness, mental health, social well being our productivity. Examples of various cultures from around the world that make design excellence a priority are examined and how they can become a precedence for making great streets, buildings and spaces in Toronto. Our walls will become your drawing board. Show us what you would design for Toronto if you were an architect. Yours may be posted on our website by June 1st.
Coloring books of our favourite buildings owned by the City of Toronto will be handed out to children.

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Founded in 1818 as "The Presbyterian Church in Scarborough". It is the oldest church in Scarborough. The present church building was built in 1849 and is early Gothic Revival. The exterior is built with local handmade bricks brought from the Don Valley Brick Works. The interior is lathe & plaster and the roof and steeple are constructed of wood. The pine floor is the original from 1849. 2 Stain Glass windows. The exterior facade above the original Gothic Doors has carvings of the builder & his wife.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: An old church with tremendous acoustics. Original floor, Bible & Altar Table. 100 year old pews, written and photographic history of the church life. Displays of today's church activities. There will be tours of the cemetery at 11am & 2pm. See the grave of the original settlers in Scarborough, David & Mary Thomson.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Our building is somewhat unusual in that the exterior is clad in rough stone, while the interior features polychrome brick-yellow brick with a banding of orange brick in geometric patterns. There are a variety of stained glass windows depicting Biblical scenes, most noticeably a dramatic portrayal of the "Road to Emmaus" story at the front of the church. Most of the windows were produced by the Toronto firm of N.T. Lyon between 1906 and 1929. Other interior items of note include the painted ceiling in the polygonal chancel, the stencilled ceiling over the main body of the church, and the organ, reportedly the first Casavant installed in a Toronto church. The building underwent major renovations in 1981-82 and we are about to begin work in the main worship space. In the first renovation, the choir stalls and organ were removed from the chancel, allowing the space to be used for innovative worship services, as well as concerts. Outside, the developers created a plaza on the north and east side of the church as part of the Renaissance Plaza complex. This juxtaposition of old and new has made the building one of the most photographed churches in the city. We welcome you!

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Visitors who come to the Church of the Redeemer during Doors Open will have an opportunity to see the main floor (worship space) area. Several exhibits of archival photographs of the church will be on display and volunteers will be available to answer questions. We will also have pictures of our planned renovations of the main space that will take place over the summer. There will be simple activities to help children explore the space with the assistance of the adults with them. On Sunday morning our regular worship services at 9.30 and 11.15 will take place. The church will be open during the services and visitors are welcome to join us.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: U of T Scarborough - Academic Resource Centre

textlist.text: Designed by award-winning architect Brian McKay-Lyons, the ARC’s copper façade complements UTSC’s internationally recognized architecture. Using a simple palate of wood, copper and concrete, ARC was designed and built economically, 15 per cent under budget. Its unique design marries elements of art, science and technology, and reflects the position of the campus at the forefront of IT-based education and research.

The ARC integrates conventional library, teaching, and learning services with state-of-the-art computing and fibre-optic networking power, multimedia production and a 500-seat performance and lecture theatre that will greatly enrich the educational environment at UTSC.

At the heart of the ARC is one of Canada’s first digital libraries where students, teachers, and researchers are guided by specialized staff to produce multimedia essays, presentations and artwork for direct submission to faculty or use in the classroom.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Guests will have the opportunity to tour the Academic Resource Centre on all floors. There will be information packages provided to allow for a more comprehensive understanding of what each space is used for.

entrydata.name: txtS3nStreetcar
entrydata.text: 116E from Kennedy or 38 from Scarborough Town Centre

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Tollkeeper's Cottage is the only known surviving tollhouse in Canada and of of six vertical plank-constructed buildings in Ontario. Sitting at the original intersection where it collected tolls, it has been restored to its earliest state and furnished to 1860 for a family of nine. It is owned and operated by a volunteer local historical society.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Docents in period dress will describe the road system of early Ontario, and the lives of the hard-working families who collected the tolls. There will be a limerick contest with prizes each day.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Originally constructed in 1879 as the West Presbyterian Church, the building was purchased for the Polish congregation of Toronto on the 15th of April 1911, by Eugene O'Keefe, a Canadian philanthropist and Private Chamberlain to His Holiness Pope Pius X. As a result of these beginnings, St. Stanislaus Kostka R.C. Church traces its architectural roots to the Gothic Revival style typical of earlier Protestant architectural traditions in North America. The interior arrangement consists of congregation seating on the first floor fashioned in a semi-circular arrangement around the alter, with a large second storey horseshoe gallery directly overhead. The cathedral ceiling is ribbed in a manner most typical of the early gothic tradition. In 1969, the parish welcomed Cardinal Karol Wojtyla, the future Pope John Paul II, as a guest.

textlist.text: St. Slanislaus Kostka R.C. Church will facilitate self guided tours of the church and its adjoining hall. Large format mounted prints will be on display to greet the visitor, elucidating the evocative history of the parish’s establishment and its relationship to the surrounding community within the catholic context of the Archdiocese of Toronto.
Within the parish interior the public will be treated to organ music along with a slide show displaying the vibrant history of this parish through its 99 years of existence.

An active Polish dance troupe, practising on Saturdays within the hall itself, will present a particularly delightful first hand experience to those who visit on this day. All of these elements assist in constructing a visual insight into Toronto's Polish community and their cultural connection to the parish as a nucleus of local community life.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

textlist.text: Designed in 1966 as a “workshop for the mind,” the office of Moriyama & Teshima is an ‘urban oasis’ in the heart of Toronto.

That the building was originally an automotive service station is fitting, as architecture is also a service business. Illustrating the transformative powers of good design, the service station is now a ‘staff-centered’ workplace, and the old grease pit is a shallow pool filled with Japanese Koi; a pool that transforms the foyer into a welcoming and meditative space.

From the clamour of the City, visitors arrive through an ivy-covered arbor and iron gateway into a peaceful forecourt that features water, wood and stone in a lush setting. Designed as a transitional space, the stress of the city ebbs away as one traverses the forecourt to the large wooden office door.

Inside the building, the design of the studios celebrates the uniting of people in a creative pursuit: there are no doors, no office cubicles. Instead, the studios are organized on multiple levels that overlap with interconnecting stairways and open views. Flooded with natural light, the work spaces are uplifting and invite constant interaction, fostering the collaborative philosophy of M&T.
Visitors to the office will have the opportunity to meet architects, discover our unique design environment and learn about recent projects.
Designers will be on-hand to welcome and answer questions.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Constructed in 1999, McKinsey & Company's building is a contemporary response to the academic architecture of its neighbour, Victoria College. This 3-storey building forms a U around a street-level courtyard, which is viewable from the public sidewalk on the west side. Building materials include copper, pale Algonquin limestone, teak and mahogany woods, and huge swaths of glass. The building has won several architectural awards.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: From our front door at 110 Charles Street West, you will enter our Reception area and client world and then will be given the opportunity to tour the ground floor of this private office building. ***PLEASE NOTE: MCKINSEY BUILDING IS OPEN ON SUNDAY ONLY, THE TORONTO STAR PROGRAM GUIDE IS INCORRECT.
Siamak Hariri; Taylor Hariri Pontarini architects, 1999

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Citytv and OMNI Television, Rogers Studios

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Originally designed to promote Toronto’s bid for the Olympic Games, Rogers Studios was completely renovated by Quadrangle Architects Limited, to provide a state-of-the-art broadcast facility for Citytv and OMNI Television.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: For the first time ever, Rogers Studios at 33 Dundas Street East will open its doors to the public during Doors Open 2010! Visitors will get a behind-the-scenes look into the street front studio space of Citytv and OMNI Television. In addition, representatives from Quadrangle Architects Limited, will reveal their process of retrofitting the new building, which forms a vibrant architectural focus and adds visual interest in the intensely urban public space of Yonge-Dundas Square.

entrydata.name: txtPA1aBldName
entrydata.text: Chinese Cultural Centre of Greater Toronto

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: The Phase I building of the Chinese Cultural Centre of Great Toronto was opened in 1998. This 23,000 square feet facility consists of: a library/resource centre, a reception hall, an art gallery, a number of studios for arts and crafts, conference rooms, and other supportive facilities. The design concepts employed by the architects focused on making the building flexible, inviting, functional and symbolic. Natural light through clerestory skylights is complemented by suspended lantern-like fixtures. Inside finishes, colours and details were inspired by the traditional Chinese fine arts of architecture, gardens, paintings, ceramics and artifacts, and by the five essential elements: metal, wood, water, fire and earth. The building design is modern but the connections to traditional Chinese architectural cultures are rich and deep. The Phase II facility of the Chinese Cultural Centre consists of a total of 56,000 square feet of facilities. It includes a 600 seat Performing Arts Theatre and an 8,500 square feet Multi-Purpose Hall. The complete complex of the Chinese Cultural Centre of Greater Toronto is currently the most comprehensive Chinese cultural centre in North America.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: Our volunteers will showcase Chinese architectural features hidden within a modern architectural design, the various objects of art in the building, Chinese furnitures, and features of the state-of-the-art performing arts theatre.

entrydata.name: radS3zDistrict
entrydata.text: South (former City of Toronto and East York)

entrydata.name: mmoS3oBldDesc
entrydata.text: Architecturally, Christie House is a beautiful example of late Victorian style set prominently amongst other houses of that era along Queen’s Park Circle East. The porte-cochere and the crow-stepped parapet gables are of particular interest. The interior of the house is dominated by the grand staircase (reflected in the new Atrium) that runs from the basement to the third floor, and is capped with a magnificent oculus. The ground floor includes a parlor with built-in cabinets and a secret door, a grand hall with an ornate vaulted ceiling, a sitting room and a dining room dominated by large fireplaces and intricate ceiling plasterwork, and a sun room with marble floors, skylights, and large vaulted windows.

entrydata.name: mmoS3sBldExper
entrydata.text: On the Doors Open Toronto weekend there will be regular tours of the building including the secret door and passage. The principal architect for the renovation of the building will give several talks. There will be a scavenger hunt with prizes for the children.
